loans.use: To purchase cloth

loans.name: Ana Mag-Usara Group

texts.en:
Ana M. is from the village of Bato. She is 55 years old. Ana is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ana is single. To make a living, Ana owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting rice for sale. Ana has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Ana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Ana is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Ana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Laila S. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal out of her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Laila is 39 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a charcoal store.

Saidia E. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell.  Saidia is 20 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has one child and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
A very determined and hardworking lady, D. Charity, aged 28 years, has been in the education sector for four years. She is a single mother with one child undergoing nursery school.

This loan is to help Charity buy household items that include chairs and mattresses and cater for her family basic needs in order to improve on her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase household items like matresses, saucepans and a bed

loans.name: Elvy Torres Group

texts.en:
Elvy T. is from the village of Bato. She is 26 years old. Elvy is the group leader for a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are each responsible for paying back the loan of the other group member, if the other one is delinquent or defaults.

Elvy is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Elvy owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Elvy has been engaged in her business for over 8 years, and she earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Elvy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Elvy is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Elvy from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret A. is currently in the business of selling bread and charcoal  and is requesting a loan to stock more charcoal to sell.  Margret is 39 years old and is widowed. She has 5 children and 3 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to continue to send her children to school.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Tehega

texts.en:
Tehega S. is currently in the business of selling bedsheets and dresses at the market and is requesting a loan to stock shoes and sandals to sell.  Tehega is 38 years old and is widowed. She has 6 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock shoes and sandals to sell

loans.name: Gohar

texts.en:
Gohar A. is 44 years old. She lives in Ijevan city with her husband and two school-aged children: a daughter and a son. From 1990 till 2003 Gohar was work in Ijevan School as a teacher. Then she migrated with her family to the Russian Federation but they returned to their motherland in 2005.

Since 2006 Gohar has been engaged in a hardware business. Her husband has a separate business: he manages a food shop. With the profit from their businesses, Gohar and her husband manage to cover their family's needs. Also, Gohar’s family have built a new house and bought furniture and consumer equipment for their house.

Gohar needs 1.100.000 AMD loan to buy linoleum and glazed tiles for her shop.

loans.use: To buy linoleum and glazed tiles for her shop

loans.name: Lolita Mutia Group

texts.en:
Lolita M. is from the village of Mangidkid. She is 55 years old. Lolita is the group leader for a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lolita is married and has four grown children. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years, and she earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the 18th loan taken out by Lolita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Beneficta Dangcalan Group

texts.en:
Beneficta D. is from the village of Naga, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Beneficta is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults.

Beneficta is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Beneficta owns & operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Beneficta has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Beneficta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beneficta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Beneficta is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Beneficta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Kenya! This is 41-year-old Jane B. from Kitale. She is married with seven children between the ages of 7 and 25 who all attend school. Jane runs a farm from which she sells vegetables, tomatoes, avocadoes and sweet potatoes at the local market. She has been farming for ten years and has one employee from the community.
Jane has requested a loan for 31,200 KES in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She hopes to buy two additional cows in the future. Jane is ambitious, and in the next five years hopes to become the main supplier of milk to the local market. The main challenge she faces is finding enough clean water and napier grass to feed her cow.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Mrs. Lolita S. is from the village of Fuentes Subdivision of Aguada, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old, married, and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Lolita runs a sari-sari store. She has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Lolita joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used as capital for her existing sari-sari store business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions, especially in meeting their basic needs and saving for future use and possible business expansion.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional materials for her shop. loans.name: Davit

texts.en: Davit D. was born in 1970 and lives in Ijevan city. He is married and has two school-aged children. His wife does not have a job – she stays at home and takes care of their children. Since 1997, Davit has run a bakery business in Ijevan city. With the profit from his bakery production, Davit keeps his family and has also set up a lemonade production business, which brings in good revenue. Davit is asking for a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy a stove for baking lavash (Armenian bread).

loans.use: To buy a stove for baking lavash (Armenian bread)

loans.name: Léonie

texts.fr: A. Léonie est née le 27 Janvier 1956 et est mariée à VINOUGNON Pierre. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Léonie vit avec sa famille au quartier Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis une dizaine d’année. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Léonie n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Léonie vend en gros de l’eau minérale « pur water ». Léonie s’approvisionne au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin ; et aussi à la SONEB au Bénin. Léonie exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d’année. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de cinq prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Léonie désire augmenter davantage son fonds de roulement et son stock de produit, ce qui lui permettra de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C’est pour cette raison que Léonie sollicite un autre crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Léonie A. was born on 27th January 1956 and is married to Pierre VINOUGNON. The couple has two children who are both at school. Léonie has lived with her family in the Dieffa district of the municipality of Sèmè-Podji for around ten years. The couple cover the various family expenses between them. Léonie never went to school. In order to provide for her needs, she sells "pur water" mineral water on a wholesale basis. She gets her supplies in Nigeria, a neighboring state to Bénin, and also at the SONEB (Société Nationale des Eaux du Bénin) in Bénin. Léonie has been carrying out this activity for around ten years. She is an old customer of ALIDé, having already benefited from five loans, all of which have been repaid in full. Léonie would like to increase her working capital and her stock of goods; this will allow her to satisfy customer demand more readily. It is for this reason that she is requesting another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sachets of water on a wholesale basis

loans.name: Mahussi Fohounvou

texts.fr: H. V. Mahussi Fohounvou  est née le 23 Mars 1974 et vit depuis vingt huit ans environs à Agata à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à KOTIN Pierre, un revendeur, Mahussi Fohounvou est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. Mahussi Fohounvou vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges du foyer. Mahussi Fohounvou n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins, Mahussi Fohounvou vend divers articles (savons de lessive et de toilette, sucre, lait, conserves de tomate et de sardine, couscous, riz, pâtes alimentaires, etc.) dans sa boutique située à Agata. Mahussi Fohounvou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Mahussi Fohounvou sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue d’élever le niveau de son activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu.
texts.en:
Mahussi Fohounvou H. V. was born on the 23rd of March, 1974 and has lived in Agata, a part of Cotonou, Benin's administrative capital, for around 28 years. She is married to Pierre Kotin, a salesman, and is a mother of five school-aged children, and has another child in her care. Mahussi Fouhounvou assists her husband and helps him with the various household tasks. She never attended school, and now has a shop in Agata selling sells various products, including detergent soap, body soap, sugar, milk, tomato and sardine paste, couscous, rice, pasta etc. She sources her goods from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Mahussi has already received loans from ALIDé and has successfully repaid them all; she is now seeking a fifth in order to improve her living conditions and to boost her profits and revenues.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various products (soap, sugar, rice, pasta, pastes etc)

loans.name: Léonie

texts.fr: Née en 1950, G. Léonie vit depuis trente ans environs, au quartier Jéricho à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Léonie est mère de six enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés ; mais Léonie ne vit plus avec son mari. Léonie vit donc seule avec ses enfants et assure leurs charges. Léonie n’a pas été à l’école. Léonie vend des tissus et des ustensiles de cuisine en plastique à Jéricho et environs. Mais Léonie achète ses articles à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cette activité lui fait générer des revenus qui l’aident à subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Léonie est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a bien effectué les remboursements de crédits qu’elle avait obtenus. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Léonie sollicite à nouveau un prêt de ALIDé, en vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1950, Léonie Bnonlonfoun has lived in the Jericho quarter of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, for around thirty years. She has six children, some of whom attend school; however, she does not live with her husband, but rather looks after her children by herself. She never went to school, and now sells fabric and plastic cooking utensils in Jericho and the surrounding area. She sources these goods from Dantokpa, Benin's international market, and this business enables her to generate revenues which go towards the cost of looking after her children. She has already received loans from ALIDé and has successfully repaid them. In the face of increasing demand from her customers, she is seeking a new loan to boost her stock and better satisfy their demands.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plastic cooking utensils and fabric

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr: A. Célestine est née en 1960 et vit depuis trente cinq ans environs au quartier Agata à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à CODJO Toussaint, Célestine est mère de six enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Mais trois des enfants restent encore à la charge de Célestine et de son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la famille. Célestine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis dix huit ans environs, Célestine vend divers articles (conserves de tomate et de sardine, lait, huile d’arachide, savons, bougies, biscuits, farine de manioc, etc.) dans son quartier. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Célestine achète ses produits. Célestine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq prêts qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Célestine souhaite augmenter son stock de produits pour mieux répondre à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle et se faire plus de profits. C’est donc pour renforcer son activité que Célestine sollicite un autre prêt.
texts.en:
Célestine A. was born in 1960 and has lived in the Agata quarter of Cotonou, Benin's administrative capital, for around 35 years. She is married to Toussaint Codjo and has six children; some of them attend school, but three are still under Célestine and her husband's care. The couple share the family demands between them. Célestine never attended school, and for around 8 years she has sold various products (tomato and sardine pastes, milk, peanut oil, soap, candles, manioc flour etc) in and around her quarter. She sources her goods from Dantokpa, Benin's international market. She has already received and successfully repaid 5 loans from ALIDé, and is seeking another in order to increase her inventory levels to better satisfy her customers' demands and to generate more profit.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing pastes, soap, insecticide, peanut oil etc

loans.name: Noélie Chantal

texts.fr: Née en 1975, A. Noélie Chantal vit au quartier Gbèdjromédé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Noélie Chantal a deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais Noélie Chantal n’est pas mariée. Noélie Chantal vit donc seule avec ses deux enfants à Gbèdjromédé, et assure seule leurs différentes charges. Noélie Chantal a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire et a appris ensuite la coiffure. Noélie Chantal exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d’année. Parallèlement, Noélie Chantal vend des mèches, des produits de beauté et aussi des tissus dans son atelier situé dans son quartier. Noélie Chantal achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la première fois que Noélie Chantal sollicite un prêt de ALIDé, en vue d’agrandir son atelier et de mieux répondre à sa clientèle ; ce qui lui permettra de se faire plus de revenus.
texts.en:
Noélie Chantal A. was born in 1975 in the Gbèdjromédé quarter of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. She has two children who attend school. She is not married, but lives with her children in Gbèdjromédé, seeing to their needs by herself. She left school at secondary level, and learned to become a hairdresser, a field that she has now been involved in for over ten years. She also sells hair pieces, beauty products and fabric in her studio which is located in her local quarter; she sources her goods from Dantokpa, Benin's international market. It is her first time seeking a loan from ALIDé, and she intends to use it to increase her studio and better satisfy her customers' demands, thereby generating more revenue.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase boxes of hair pieces, hair products and fabric

loans.name: Arshak

texts.en:
Arshak was born in Sarigyugh village, in the Ijevan area, in 1966. He is married and has three children: his son is serving in the Armenian army, one of his daughters is married and lives separately from her parents, and his younger daughter is a pupil. For a long time, Arshak has been engaged in animal husbandry and land cultivation. During this time he has been able to keep his family, repair his apartment, pay for his elder daughter’s education and organize her wedding. Arshak likes his occupation very much and shares with us that this year one of his cows is to give birth to twin calves, which is a unique occurrence.   
Arshak is requesting a 400,000 AMD loan to transport his farm animals to the mountains and pay rent for a plot of land where he will do hay mowing in the summer.

loans.use: To transport his farm animals to the mountains and pay rent for a plot of land for hay mowing

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr: H. Louise est née en 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à AYAMOU Zacharie, un mécanicien, Louise est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Il y a une dizaine d’année que Louise vit au quartier Sainte Rita à Cotonou, avec sa petite famille. Louise assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la famille. Louise n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Il y a environs trois ans que Louise a commencé la vente de diverses sortes de biscuits et de bombons à Sainte Rita. Louise vend également des sacs. Louise achète ses articles à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Louise est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Dans le but d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de rehausser le niveau de son activité, afin d’augmenter sa part de marché, Louise sollicite un quatrième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Louise H. was born in 1977 in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. She is married to Zacharie Ayamou, a mechanic, and has three children who all attend school. She has lived in the Sainte Rita quarter of Cotonou with her family for around ten years, and she and her husband work together to look after their family's needs. Louise left school after primary level; around three years ago she began to sell different sorts of biscuits and sweets in Sainte Rita; she also sells bags. She buys her goods from Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Louise has already received and repaid three loans from ALIDé and is seeking her fourth in order to increase her business funds and boost her business activity so that she may gain market share.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sweets, biscuits and bags

loans.name: Séraphine

texts.fr: T. Séraphine est mariée à DOSSA Marcellin, un chauffeur. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont à leurs charges. Séraphine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Kindonou, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Séraphine assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la famille. Séraphine n’est jamais allée à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Séraphine vend du haricot, mais aussi du « chapalot » (boisson local, fait à base du maïs et du sucre) à Cococodji et à Kindonou. Séraphine s’approvisionne aux marchés de Cococodji et de Cocotomey à Cotonou. Séraphine mène cette activité depuis trois ans environs et a déjà bénéficié une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Séraphine a bien remboursé ledit crédit. Face à la demande nombreuse de sa clientèle, Séraphine sollicite un deuxième prêt afin de rehausser le niveau de son activité. Séraphine envisage plus tard diversifier son activité par la vente d’autres produits.
texts.en:
Séraphine T. is married to Marcellin DOSSA, a driver. The couple has four children, all of whom have attended school and three of whom are in their care. Séraphine lives with her children and her husband in Kindonou, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Séraphine shares the responsibility for the various family expenses with her husband. She has never been to school. In order to provide for her needs, she sells beans, but also "chapalot" (a local drink made out of corn and sugar) in Cococodji and in Kindonou. Séraphine gets her supplies at the markets in Cococodji and in Coctomey in Cotonou. She has been carrying out this activity for around three years and has already benefited from one loan from ALIDé. She repaid this loan in full. Faced with increasing customer demand, Séraphine is requesting a second loan so that she can increase the level of her activity. She envisages diversifying her activities later on with the sale of other products.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn and sugar for the preparation of "Chapalot", and beans

loans.name: Adiaratou

texts.fr:
Madame Adiaratou  Koné a 41 ans, mariée et mère de 7 enfants. Elle vit  avec son mari,  sa coépouse et  leurs  enfants, dans une famille polygame, dans le quartier Darsalam II de la préfecture de Koutiala.  
Madame Adiaratou n’a pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école, raison pour laquelle elle s’est très vite intéressée au commerce depuis son enfance auprès de sa mère. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus, elle finit par opter pour  l’activité d’achat et de vente d’habits wax depuis  plus de vingt ans. Sa notoriété est bonne car elle reçoit plusieurs commandes dans le mois. 
Pour l’agrandissement de son activité et la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle, elle n’a pas pris du temps à rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2 ans.  Madame Adiaratou, après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) auprès de Soro Yiriwaso tous correctement  remboursés, elle est à son 1er prêt individuel. 
Elle s’approvisionne auprès des commerçants du grand marché de Bamako (capitale du Mali) et souvent à Koutiala et compte acheter, 10 pièces de tissus wax. 
Elle effectue sa  vente dans la ville de Koutiala et  dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants à crédit et au comptant. 
Elle  compte réaliser un bénéfice  mensuel de 75.000FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt  de Soro Yiriwaso et participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.  
Madame Adiaratou ambitionne ouvrir une boutique de vente d’habits et divers dans le marché de Koutiala.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adiaratou Koné is 41 years old, married and the mother of seven children. She lives with her husband, her husband’s second wife and their children, as a polygamous family, in the Darsalam II district in the Koutiala prefecture. Mrs. Adiaratou did not have an opportunity to go to school, and this is why she started learning a business from her mother at an early age. After trying several commercial activities, she has settled on purchasing and reselling “wax” clothing [made of traditional colorful fabrics], which she has been practicing for more than 20 years now. Her business is popular, and she receives many orders each month. In order to grow her business and better satisfy customer demand, she wasted no time in joining the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. She has been a member for two years and had four solidarity (group) loans, all of which were duly repaid. She is now on her first individual loan. She purchases her stock from the vendors at the big market of Bamako (the capital of Mali) and often in Koutiala; she plans to purchase ten sets of “wax” fabric. She sells her wares in the town of Koutiala as well as at the weekly markets in neighboring towns, on credit or for cash. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 75,000 West African Francs, which she intends to use to repay her loan interest to Soro Yiriwaso and contribute to the everyday family expenses. Her goal is to open a shop selling clothing and miscellaneous items at the Koutiala market.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing of traditional fabrics [for resale]

loans.name: Prisca

texts.fr: Née en 1982 à Bohicon dans le département du Zou, B. Prisca vit depuis sept ans environs à Kindonou, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Prisca est mariée à TCHEHOUENOU François, un couturier, et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Prisca vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple se partage les charges familiales. Prisca n’a pas été à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Prisca vend des chaussures et aussi des tissus au marché de Kindonou à Cotonou. Prisca achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Prisca exerce cette activité depuis six ans et a obtenu une fois déjà un crédit  auprès de ALIDé. Prisca a bien effectué le remboursement de ce prêt. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Prisca sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1982 in Bohicon in the "département" of Zou, Prisca B. has lived for around seven years in Kindonou, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Prisca is married to François TCHEHOUENOU, a tailor, and is mother to one child who is at school. She lives with her husband and child. The couple shares responsibility for the family's expenses. Prisca did not go to school. In order to provide for her needs, she sells shoes and also fabrics at the Kindonou market in Cotonou. Prisca buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin's international market. She has been carrying out this activity for six years and has already had one loan from ALIDé. She repaid this loan without incident. With the aim of expanding her business and coping better with customer demand, Prisca is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of shoes and damask fabric

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Âgée de 50 ans, Madame Aminata Kassongué est mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari et ses  enfants dans le quartier Kouloukoro  de la ville  de Koutiala. 
N’ayant pas eu la chance de faire de brillante étude,  Aminata s’est très vite intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus avec l’achat vente de diverses marchandises telle les condiments  et  la farine de blé. 
Elle exerce cette activité depuis plus de 11 ans. 
Pour pouvoir combattre les petites ruptures qu’elle subit  fréquemment, qui la fait perdre de la clientèle, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle  il y a 6 ans.  
Après avoir  8 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) tous correctement  payés,   elle est à son 3e  prêt individuel dont les deux précédents ont été correctement  remboursés.  
Elle compte acheter  des sacs de farine de blé auprès des grossistes à Koutiala et effectue sa vente  au marché Kouloukoro et à son domicile à une clientèle  essentiellement  féminine, au comptant et à crédit.  
Avec le renforcement de son fonds de commerce, elle compte sur un bénéfice moyen de 75.000FCFA  par mois  qu’elle envisage  utiliser  pour payer les  intérêts du prêt de Soro, participer aux dépenses familiales et s’entretenir elle même ainsi que ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aminata Kassongué is 50 years old, married and mother to eight children. She lives with her husband and children in the Kouloukoro district of the town of Koutiala. Since she did not have the chance to shine in her studies, Aminata became interested at an early age in income-generating activities, notably with the purchase and sale of various goods such as condiments and wheat flour. She has been carrying out this activity for more than 11 years. In order to overcome the small ruptures in stock which she experiences frequently and which lead to her losing customers, she decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso six years ago, to be able to satisfy her customer demand. Having had eight group loans, all of which she repaid on time, she is now on her third individual loan (the two previous ones having also been repaid on time). She is planning on buying sacks of wheat flower from wholesalers in Koutiala; she sells her goods at the Kouloukoro market and at home to a customer base which is predominantly feminine, for cash and on credit. With the reinforcement of her business, she expects to make an average profit of 75,000FCFA per month, which she plans to use to pay the interest on her loan from Soro, to contribute to her family's expenses and to look after herself as well as her children.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wheat flour

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata Samaké est âgée de 39 ans, veuve et   mère  de 5 enfants. Elle  vit avec ses enfants  dans le quartier Médina coura de la préfecture de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso ). 
Ayant vite abandonnée l’école,  pour des raisons sociales, elle embrassa  tôt les activités génératrices de revenus depuis son jeune âge, auprès de sa maman. 
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle finit par opter pour  l’achat et la vente du bois de chauffe il y a 2 ans.  
Pour  combattre ses ruptures et satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle, elle n’a pas pris du temps à rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  depuis 5 ans.  
Après  5 prêts solidaires tous payés correctement, elle est à son 4eme prêt individuel dont les trois précédents ont été payés sans difficulté.  
Madame Fatoumata compte utiliser ce prêt pour l’achat, d’un chargement de camion remorque en bois de chauffe auprès des paysans des villages  environnants  Koutiala  et elle effectue sa vente  devant sa porte.   
Madame Fatoumata  compte réaliser un   bénéfice  de 75 000 FCFA par mois qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts, satisfaire le besoin  de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité..
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Samaké is 39 years old, a widow and mother to five children. She lives with her children in the Médina Coura district of the prefecture (administrative region) of Koutiala (in the region of Sikasso). Since she left school rapidly, for social reasons, she began her income-generating activities at an early age, with her mother. Having tried out several activities without success, she finished by opting for the purchase and sale of firewood two years ago. In order to overcome ruptures of stock and to satisfy customer needs, she did not waste any time joining the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. After five group loans, all of which were repaid in full, she is now on her fourth individual loan, the three preivous loans having been repaid without difficulty. Fatoumata is planning on using this loan for the purchase of a lorry trailer load of firewood from peasants in the surrounding villages of Koutiala and she sells it in front of her door. She is planning on making a profit of 75,000FCFA a month which she will use for the repayment of interest and to satisfy her family's needs; the balance will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of firewood

loans.name: Twegatte Women's Group, Kampala

texts.en:
Her fifteen-year-old tailoring business has stood her in such good stead in her locality that laurels coming her way have been inevitable. 38-year-old K. Sarah began as a home-based seamstress until she realized her trade could bring her long drawn out financial dividends.

The future business prospects for this married mother of two are looking good, going by the 400,000 shillings Sarah makes in a month and the experience she has now gained. Her business has seen success in subsequent years because of the demand by many people for traditional wear, clothes she starting making five years ago.

Sarah’s two children have both completed school, courtesy of her business. Throughout these fifteen years in business, her reliable recourse has invariably been her good customer care skills.

With this loan, Sarah is upbeat with conviction that she will be able to buy some additional sewing machines to add to those she already has.

loans.use: To purchase additional sewing machines for her business

loans.name: Balemadjourou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Balemadjourou de l’association Lolo est composé de 4 femmes mariées à Kimparana, préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Les membres du groupe Balemadjourou  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles.  Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et ont en moyenne 45 ans et au moins 9 enfants. 
Elles exercent presque la même activité à savoir l’achat et la vente de diverses marchandises (tissus, bijoux, encens, sucre et thé). 
Les femmes du groupe ont intégré le programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans et sont à leur  8ème  prêt solidaire. 
Quant à l’utilisation du prêt,  Koroba Traoré compte acheter, 40kg de gueni, 12kg de magnokisseni, 2kg de djekalani et 16 bouteilles de parfums de tous genres. 
Koroba mélange d’abord le gueni avec le parfum eau de Cologne et le dépose pendant une semaine. La semaine suivante elle ajoute tous les parfums et le djekalani pour ensuite les mettre dans des bouteilles qui seront vendues entre  5 000 et 10 000 FCFA à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Koroba compte réaliser un bénéfice de 31000 FCFA par mois et les autres membres espèrent réaliser un bénéfice de 29500FCFA, qui va leurs permettre de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
The group Balemadjourou of the association Lolo is composed of four married women in Kimparana, Prefecture of San, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the group live in large traditional families, and they know one another through community ties, average 45 years of age, and have at least nine children. They operate nearly the same business, namely buying and selling a variety of merchandise (cloth, jewelry, incense, sugar, and tea). The group members joined the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago and are now on their eighth solidarity loan. As for the use of the loan, Koroba Traoré intends to buy 40 kg of gueni, 12 kg of magnokisseni , 2 kg of djekalani , and 16 bottles of perfumes of all types. Koroba first of all mixes the gueni with eau de ologne and lets it sit for a week. In the following week, she adds all the perfume and the djekalani and then bottles them. They will be sold for 5,000 to 10,000 francs CFA to a customer base composed essentially of women. Koroba plans on making a profit of 31,000 francs per month. And the other members hope to make a profit of 29,500 francs. The profits will enable them to repay the loan and to reinvest in enterprise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients for making incense

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkan de l’association Belle étoile est composé de 4 femmes mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du MALI). Les membres du groupe Benkan vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, se sont connues à travers le voisinage et  la  parenté et ont en moyenne 43 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe Benkan ont intégré le programme de Soro Yiriwaso depuis plusieurs années et sont à  leur 8  prêt de groupe. 
Elles font le commerce de tissus, de condiments alimentaires et de  produits cosmétiques tels Agnès C..
Quant à l’utilisation du prêt, Agnès C. qui est une vendeuse de produits cosmétiques au grand marché de San, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter à Bamako et en gros, 25 cartons de parfums de tous genres, 10cartons de mèches, 3cartons de crèmes Caro White, 3 douzaines de déodorants  OE et beaucoup d’autres articles pour la bonne marche de sa boutique. Elle revend en détail, au comptant et souvent  à crédit. 
Tandis que Agnès C. espère réaliser un bénéfice de 45000FCFA par mois les autres membres envisagent obtenir 36 000FCFA. 
Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses familiales et réinvestir dans les entreprises.
texts.en:
The Benkan group of the Beautiful Star association is composed of four married women from the city of San, in the Segou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the Benkan group live in large traditional families and came to know each other through relatives and neighbors. On average, these women are 43 years of age and have six children. The women of the Benkan group have been involved in the Soro Yiriwaso program for many years and are taking out their eighth group loan. They sell fabric, food condiments and cosmetics. Agnès C., who is a cosmetic retailer at the San market, plans to use the loan to purchase at Bamako and in wholesale, 25 boxes of all types of perfumes, 10 boxes of hair extensions, three boxes of Caro White creams, three dozen OE deodorants and many other items to sell at her shop. She sells retail, by cash and often by credit. While Agnès C. expects to receive earnings of 45 000 XOF per month, the other group members expect to receive 36 000 XOF. The earnings will be used to help meet family expenses and reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics

loans.name: Dakan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dakan de l’association Lolo est composé de 4 femmes mariées de la ville de Kimparana, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Dakan vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et au moins 8 enfants. 
Elles pratiquent les activités d’achats et de  ventes de différentes marchandises  telles les condiments alimentaires, les habits, les céréales, etc. 
Elles collaborent avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2007 d’où leur 7ème  prêt solidaire, tous les six prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Tata Fabé  qui s’est spécialisée dans la vente de condiments de toutes sortes,  afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle  qui ne cesse d’augmenter, compte  acheter, 90 paquets de maggi,  12 sacs de sel de cuisine, 40 boites de tomates  en pâtes, 2 paquets de poivres, 20kg de l’ail. 
Elle s’approvisionne en gros à San et à Koutiala pour revendre en détail, au comptant, à Kimparana à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes. 
Elle envisage réaliser 32 500FCFA de bénéfice par mois. Les autres membres du groupe comptent réaliser 29500FCFA par mois.
Elle reste convaincue qu’avec le partenariat de Soro Yiriwaso, elle ouvrira une grande boutique dans l’avenir.
texts.en:
The Dakan group of the Lolo association is composed of four married women from the city of Kimparana, in the region of Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the group live in large, traditional extended families. They came to know each other in their neighbourhood. They are 45 years old on average and have at least eight children. Their business consists of the purchase and sale of different merchandise such as food condiments, clothing, grains, etc. They have been collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso since 2007 and are taking out their seventh group loan; the previous six loans have been repaid in full. Tata Fabé is a specialist in the sale of all type of food condiments. To meet the needs of her growing clientele, she plans to buy 90 packages of maggi, 12 bags of cooking salt, 40 boxes of tomato paste, two packages of pepper, and 20 kg of garlic. She buys her supplies wholesale in San and Koutiala. She resells them in a retail shop in Kimparana on a cash basis to mostly female customers. She expects to have earnings of 32 500 XOF per month. She is convinced that as a Soro Yiriwaso partner, she will open a large shop in the future. The other members of the group expect to have earnings of 29 500 XOF per month.

Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food condiments

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya de l’association Fotemogoban est composé de 4 femmes mariées de la ville de Tènè, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Danaya vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles  élargies. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et la  parenté. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans et au moins 8 enfants.  
Elles exercent presque la même activité à savoir la vente de diverses marchandises et condiments alimentaires.
Nana Traoré qui est un membre du groupe s’est spécialisée dans la vente de condiments alimentaires de toutes sortes.  
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles  qui ne cesse d’augmenter, ces femmes ont trouvé une solution à leur problème en intégrant l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso il y a 4ans. Elles sont à leur 7ème  prêt de groupe, après avoir correctement remboursés les six précédents. 
Nana Traoré compte  acheter avec son prêt, 40 paquets de maggi,  12 sacs de sel de cuisine, 400 kg de Haricot, 2 paquets de poivres et 20kg de l’ail. 
Elle s’approvisionne en gros à San pour revendre en détail à San et à Tènè.  
Nana espère réaliser 32500FCFA de bénéfice par mois tandis que les autres membres prétendent avoir un bénéfice mensuel de 29500FCFA.
texts.en:
The group Danaya of the association Fotemogoban is composed of four married women of the city of Tènè, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members live in large traditional extended families.  They know one another through ties of community and kinship.  They average 43 years of age and have at least eight children.  And they operate nearly the same businesses, namely selling a variety of merchandise and condiments.  Nana Traoré, who is a member of the group, became specialized in selling condiments of all kinds.  In order to satisfy the needs of their ever-growing customer base, these women found a solution to their problem by having joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago.  They are now on their seventh group loan after having properly repaid the six preceding ones.    Nana Traoré plans on using her loan to buy 40 packets of Maggi (bouillon cubes), 12 sacks of table salt, 400 kg of beans, 2 packets of black pepper, and 20 kg of garlic.  She stocks up wholesale in San and then sells retail in San and in Tènè.  She hopes to make 32,500 francs CFA in profit per month, while the other members intend to make a monthly profit of 29,500 francs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying condiments

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya de l’association Kankeletigui est composé de 5 femmes mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Danaya vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et exercent les activités de petit commerce depuis plusieurs années avec la vente de diverses marchandises : tissus, fruits et légumes etc.  Elles sont toutes mariées et ont en moyenne 36 ans et au moins 4 enfants. 
Elles sont à leur première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso c'est-à-dire le premier  prêt solidaire. 
La présidente du groupe en la personne de Djeneba Koné est beaucoup sollicitée par ses clients pour la qualité  de ses fruits et légumes. 
Elle s’approvisionne chaque semaine à la foire de Sikasso et compte acheter avec son prêt ci, 10 sacs de pomme de terre, 2 sacs d’orange, un panier de tomate, un panier de carottes  et un panier de  concombres. 
Elle revend au marché de San et les foires environnants  en détail  et en gros, en espèce et à crédit. 
Tandis que Djeneba Koné espère  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 13 000 FCFA, les autres membres du groupe envisagent obtenir 11 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
The Danaya group of the Kankeletigui association is composed of five married women from the town of San in Ségou region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The group members live in large traditional families. They are well known in their neighborhood, and have been active in the business of selling a variety of merchandise for several years: they sell yard goods, fruits, vegetables and so on. On average, they are 36 years old, and each of them has at least four children. They are currently repaying their first cooperative loan from Soro Yiriwaso. . Djeneba Koné, the group's president, is valued by her customers for the quality of her fruits and vegetables. Every week she buys her provisions at the fair in Sikasso. With this loan she plans to buy 10 bags of potatoes, 2 bags of oranges, a basket of tomatoes, a basket of carrots and a basket of cucumbers. She will sell them at the market in San and at fairs in the surrounding area, retail and wholesale, for cash and credit. While Djeneba Koné hopes for a monthly income of 13,000 FCFA, the other members of the group are counting on getting 11,000 FCFA. They will use the income to pay expenses and to plow money back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djekafo de l’association  Badenyaton est composé de 5 femmes mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Djekafo vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et 7 enfants. Elles ont  une durée de collaboration de plus de 4 ans avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 9eme  prêt solidaire. 
Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers avec la vente de condiments alimentaires et  la restauration.
Batoma C. communément appelée Batoma Bakounkolo (tête de chèvre) à cause de son activité de restauration de la tête et pattes de moutons et de chèvres, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, la matière première  et les ingrédients pour la sa restauration. 
Elle achète par jour 12 têtes de moutons et de chèvres, 1kg d’oignon un panier de tomate et les autres petits condiments.
Elle se ravitaille et vend journalièrement au grand marché de San à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Batoma prétend obtenir un bénéfice de 56 000FCFA pendant que les autres membres du groupe comptent réaliser 48 000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé non seulement pour rembourser le prêt  mais venir en aide aux conjoints et réinvestir dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The Djekafo group of the Badenyaton association is composed of five married women from the city of San, in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the Djekafo group live in large, traditional families. They got to know each other in the neighborhood. On average, they are 45 years old and have seven children. They have been working with Soro Yiriwaso for more than four years and are requesting their ninth group loan. Their business involves the sale of various items such as food condiments and also a restaurant. Batoma C., who is often called Batoma Bakounkolo (goat head) because her restaurant features sheep and goat heads and feet, plans to use her loan to buy base products and ingredients for her restaurant. Each day she buys twelve heads of sheep and goats, 1 kg of onions, a basket of tomatoes and other small condiments. She restocks and then sells daily at the San market to a diverse customer base. Batoma expects to earn 56 000 XOF, while the other members of the group expect to earn 48 000 XOF per month. Their earnings will be used not only to repay the loan, but also to help their spouses and re-invest in the business.

Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for the restaurant

loans.name: Fotemogoban Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Fotemogoban de l’association Badenya est composé de 5 femmes mariées de la ville de Tènè, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Fotemogoban vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles  élargies. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et la  parenté et ont en moyenne 38 ans et au moins 4 enfants.  
Elles exercent les activités génératrices de revenus depuis plus de 10 ans et ont intégré l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de 4 ans. Elles sont à leur 7è  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les six précédents.
Les femmes du groupe font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’arachide, le riz et les condiments alimentaires. 
Touta D., un membre du groupe  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 50 sacs d’arachide  auprès  des paysans producteurs de Tènè et environs. 
Elle décortique 5 sacs par semaine pour partir les revendre à San et dans les foires environnantes à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Tandis que Touta D. espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 47000 FCFA, les autres membres du groupe envisagent obtenir 43 000 FCFA.. 
Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses familiales et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
The group Fotemogoban of the association Badenya is composed of five married women of the city of Tènè, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members live in large traditional extended families.  They know one another through ties of community and kinship.  And they average 38 years of age and have at least four children.  These woman have had income-generating businesses for over ten years and joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over four years ago.  They are now on their seventh solidarity loan after having properly repaid the six preceding ones.  The group members do commerce in a variety of goods, such as peanuts, rice, and condiments. Touta D., a member of the group, plans on using her loan for buying 50 sacks of peanuts from peasant producers in and around Tènè.  She hulls five sacks each week and goes to resell them in San and at surrounding markets.  Her customer base is compose of women and men.  While she hopes to make a monthly profit of 47,000 francs CFA, the other group members envision making 43,000 francs.  This profit will be used to provide for the family and for reinvesting in the businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying peanuts

loans.name: Kotognogotala Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kotognogotala de l’association Benkadi est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Kotognogotala vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 39 ans et au moins 5 enfants. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et exercent les activités de petit commerce depuis plusieurs années avec la vente de diverses marchandises : condiments alimentaires, beignets et les arachide grillés. 
Elles sont à leur première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso c'est-à-dire le premier prêt solidaire.
La présidente du groupe en la personne de Kadia Traoré est beaucoup sollicitée par sa  clientèle pour la qualité de  ses beignets. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter, 2kg de riz, 3kg de petit, 50FCFA de levure et  2 litres d’huile alimentaire. 
Après avoir pilé le mil elle le mélange avec du riz pour ensuite l’amener au moulin. La poudre obtenue, elle pétri avec de l’eau, du sel de cuisine et de la levure la nuit. La pâte obtenue est frite le matin pour avoir du beignet, sa clientèle est composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 12000FCFA par mois pendant que les autres membres du groupe envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 11000 FCFA. 
Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt subvenir aux  subvenir et réinvestir  dans les activités.
texts.en:
The group Kotognogotala of the association Benkadi is composed of married women of the city of San, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members live in large traditional families and average 39 years of age and have at least five children.  They know one another through ties of community and have been running small-scale businesses for several years selling a variety of merchandise:  condiments, beignets, and roasted peanuts.  The group members are now on their first experience with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is their first solidarity loan.  The president of the group, Kadia Traoré, is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her beignets.  She plans on using her loan for buying 2 kg of rice, 3 kg of pearl millet, 50 francs of leavening, and 2 liters of vegetable oil.  After pounding the millet, Kadia mixes it with rice and then takes it to the mill.  With the resulting powder, she kneads it with water, table salt, and leavening at night.  The resulting dough is fried in the morning to obtain the beignets.  Her customer base is composed of women and men.  Kadia plans on a month profit of 12,000 francs CFA, while the other group members envision making a monthly profit of 11,000 francs.  This profit will be used for repaying the loan, providing for the family, and reinvesting in the businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients for making doughnuts

loans.name: Parisi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Parisi de l’association Badenya est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tènè, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Parisi vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et la  parenté. Elles ont en moyenne  32 ans et au moins 3 enfants. 
Elles sont à leur première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso c'est-à-dire le premier prêt de groupe. 
Les membres du groupe Parisi font des activités génératrices de revenus telles les condiments, le sucre, le bois de chauffe et diverses marchandises. 
Hawa Théra est une vendeuse de condiments alimentaires du groupe qui compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter, 2 paquets de maggi, 1 sac de sel de cuisine, 5 kg de poivre, 5 kg de l’ail  et 3 kg de lauriers Ces marchandises constituent ses achats de la semaine. 
Elle compte sur un bénéfice de 13 500 FCFA par mois tandis que les membres espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 11500FCFA. 
Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, venir en aide aux conjoints et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
The group Parisi of the association Badenya is composed of married women of the city of Tènè, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members live in large traditional families.  They know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they average 32 years of age and have at least three children.   The group members are now on their first experience with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  In other words, this is their first group loan.  They have income-generating businesses such as in condiments, sugar, firewood, and various goods.  Hawa Théra is a seller of the group's condiments, and she intend to use her loan for buying 2 packets of Maggi (bouillon cubes), a sack of table salt, 5 kg of black pepper, 5 kg of garlic, and 3 kg of bay leaves.  These goods constitute her purchases for the week.  Hawa plans on a profit of 13,5000 francs CFA per month, while the group members hope to make a monthly profit of 11,500 francs.  This profit will be used for repaying the loan, helping out their husbands, and reinvesting in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying condiments

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Sabali  est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou quatrième  (région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Sabali vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 46 ans et au moins 7 enfants. Elles ont une expérience solide dans le commerce  d’articles divers  avec la vente de condiments,  de tissus et  de bijoux. 
Ces femmes sont à leurs 7ème  prêt de groupe avec Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés sans aucune difficulté.
Quant à l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, Kadia T. compte utiliser le sien pour acheter, à Bamako 1 balle de pagnes wax contenant 50 pièces  pour les revendre à San, en détail en espèce et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Tandis que Madame Kadia T. espère sur un bénéfice de 23.500FCFA par mois les autres membres du groupe eux comptent sur un bénéfice de 21 000FCFA par mois.
Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, venir en aide aux familles et réinvestir dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
The group Sabali is composed of married women of the city of Tènè, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members live in large traditional families, and they average 46 years of age and have at least seven children.  They have solid experience in commerce selling a variety of goods: condiments, cloth, and jewelry.  These women are on their seventh group loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  Each of their preceding loans have been repaid with any difficulties at all.  As for the use of this new loan, Kadia T. plans on using hers for buying, in Bamako:  a bale of wax pagnes  (colorful West African cloth) containing 50 lengths to be sold retail in San.  She accepts cash or credit from a customer base composed of women and men.  While Kadia hope for a profit of 23,500 francs CFA per month, the other group members are counting on a profit of 21,000 francs per month.  This profit will be used for repaying the loan, helping out their families, and reinvesting in the enterprise. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth

loans.name: Ekyerisho Traders, Mubende Group

texts.en:
With two children of his own and two dependents to take care of, 40-year-old, hard working, M. Emmanuel knows he has his responsibilites cut out for him. This reality has looked him in the face for the past seven years as he goes about his trivial round business of selling alcohol in Ekyerisho, Mubende District.

With his minimal 280,000 shillings a month of earnings, Emmanuel has faced long odds in providing all his family’s needs, principally his children’s education. He wants to improve on the status quo of his family with the acquisition of this loan as he wants to give his business an improved lease of life in terms of expansion through restocking.

loans.use: To restock and expand his business

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya de l’association Benkadi est composé de 6  femmes mariées de la ville de Tènèni, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le commerce d’articles divers  tels le poisson (à l’image de Messitan D.), les habits, le  riz, le gombo et). il y’a environ 15 ans. 
Afin de satisfaire leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ 1 an. 
Messitan la vendeuse de poisson compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 6 paniers de poissons auprès des grossistes et revend en détail et au comptant à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes.
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe  comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 18 000 FCFA par mois, Messitan, elle, espère avoir 21 000 FCFA par mois. 
Les membres du groupe compte avoir un montant de prêt  plus élevé avec Soro Yiriwaso pour pouvoir se ravitailler en condiments en gros à Bamako
NB : Mah Boïté est absente de la photo pour raison de santé
texts.en:
The group Djiguiya of the association Benkadi is compose of six married women of the city of Tènèni, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members live in traditional families, and they average 35 years of age and have at least five children.  They do commerce in a variety of goods, such as fish (like Messitan D.), clothing, rice, okra, etc, for about fifteen years.  In order to satisfy their customers, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about a year ago.  Messitan, the fish seller, plans on using her loan for buying six baskets of fish from wholesalers and then selling them retail.  She accepts cash from a customer base composed essentially of women.  While the other group members plan on making a profit of 18,000 francs CFA per month, Messitan herself hopes to earn 21,000 francs a month. The group members expect to obtain a higher loan amount with Soro Yiriwaso in order to be able to resupply themselves with condiments in bulk, in Bamako.  Note:  Mah Boïté is absent from the photo for health reasons. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fish

loans.name: Horonya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Horonya de l’association  Benkadi est composé femmes mariées de la ville de Tènèni, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et se sont connues à travers le voisinage. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et 7 enfants. 
Elles ont une expérience d’une année avec Soro Yiriwaso et exercent le commerce de condiments alimentaires  et la  restauration. 
Mata Koïta  qui est une des restauratrice du groupe compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, les ingrédients et le poisson  à des fins de restauration. 
Elle achète par jour 12 panier de poisson, 1kg d’oignon un panier de tomate et les autres petits condiments. 
Elle se ravitaille au grand marché de Tènèni et vend ses plats alimentaires à une clientèle diverse et variée.
Mata espère sur un bénéfice de 12 000FCFA pendant que les autres membres du groupe comptent réaliser 8 000 FCFA par mois. 
Ce bénéfice servira non seulement pour rembourser le prêt, venir en aide aux conjoints et réinvestir dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The group Horonya of the association Benkadi is composed of married women of the city of Tènèni, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members live in large traditional families, and they know one another through neighborhood ties.  They average 45 years of age and have at least seven children.  The group members have one year of experience with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and they do commerce in condiments and in food catering.  Mata Koïta, one of the restauranteurs in the group, plans on using her loan for buying fish and the ingredients for food catering purposes. Each day, she purchases twelve baskets of fish, 1 kg of onions, a basket of tomatoes, and sundry other condiments.  She resupplies herself at the big market of Tènèni. She sells her dishes to a diverse and varied customer base. Mata is hoping for a profit of 12,000 francs CFA, while the other group members plan on making 8,000 francs per month.  This profit will be used not only for repaying the loan but also for helping out their husbands and reinvesting in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients for food catering

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr: Fatoumata B. est une femme de 21 ans, elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KAMBENG DOUMASSOU depuis 2 ans et demis et a 5 fois de suite reçu de crédit et a toujours bien géré ses prêts et remboursé à temps. Elle est détentrice d'une boutique où elle vend différents produits alimentaires. Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer sa boutique en achetant beaucoup plus de marchandises telles que des produits détergents, du riz, de l'huile végétale, du sucre, des boîtes de conserves etc.Elle est soutenu dans son activité par son mari par rapport au transport de la marchandise lors de l'approvisionnement. Son objectif est de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatoumata B. is 21 years old, married and the mother of one child. She has been a member of the KAMBENG DOUMASSOU «Banc Villageois» loan group for 2 ½ years and has been granted five successive loans, all well managed and repaid on time. She owns a shop where she sells various food products (rice, vegetable oil, sugar, etc.) and detergents. This loan will help her grow her business by allowing her to buy large stocks of merchandise such as rice, detergents, vegetable oil, sugar, canned goods, etc. Her husband helps her transport merchandise when she needs to resupply. Her objective is to participate in improving the family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Renforcer sa capital d'investissement et de faire la promotion de son activité

loans.name: Rokhaya

texts.fr: Rokhaya S. est une femme de 40 ans elle est divorcée et vit avec ses 5 enfants dont elle a l'entière charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KAMBENG DOUMASSOU depuis 3 ans. Elle développe un commerce de tissu, de vêtement et de chaussures. Et son nouveau crédit lui permettra de mieux approvisionner sa boutique en marchandises telles que des tissus, des vêtements et des chaussures. Son objectif est d'assurer la prise en charge de sa progéniture et de subvenir à ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
Rokhaya S. is 40 years old, divorced and living with her five children of whom she is the sole provider. She has been a member of the KAMBENG DOUMASSOU « Banc Villageois » loan group for three years. She is developing a business selling clothing fabric, clothes and shoes. This loan will allow her to stock her boutique better with fabrics, clothing and shoes. Her objective is to ensure her children are well provided for and meet her own personal needs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Reinforce her ability for self-financing

loans.name: Twegatte Women's Group, Mukono

texts.en:
38-year-old N. Justine has reckoned on earnings from her ten-year-old retail shop in the heart of Kayiringuto trading center in Mukono to foster the welfare of her family. Since she took the reins of her business, she has gained enough leverage as her business, that for the most part deals in sugar, soft drinks and foodstuffs, has enabled her to support her five children’s education.

This happily married mother was prevailed upon by close acquaintances to open up her own business. Before she ventured into her retail shop, she was a secondhand-clothes dealer.

Justine has gone to extreme lengths to ensure her monthly earnings of 400,000 shillings are consolidated. In the wake of this success have been financial and other business operational problems that she has managed to stem the tide of.

Justine has not lost sight of her desire to see her business gravitate to a wholesale franchise. With enough second thought, she has been brought to terms with the fact that this loan will come in handy in helping her to buy more retail stock like rice, sugar and crates of soda.

loans.use: To buy more general merchandise like rice, sugar and sodas

loans.name: Javier Aldo

texts.es:
Javier 36 años de edad, posee casa propia, vive  con su esposa  y sus hijos. El labora 
como maestro albañil  ya dedicándose a esta actividad 16 años, en la actualidad se 
encuentra laborando para una empresa constructora de la región, demostrando 
responsabilidad y honradez en sus labores diarias y por este motivo es que ya tiene 
varios años laborando en dicha empresa, el sueña con poder reconstruir su vivienda la 
cual fue afectada por el terremoto, y por el momento su familia se encuentra viviendo 
en malas condiciones, requiere el crédito para la compra materiales de construcción.
texts.en:
Javier, 36, owns his own house, where he lives with his wife and their children. He works as a master bricklayer; he has done this work for 16 years. Currently he is working for a construction company in the region, demonstrating responsibility and honor in his daily work. For this reason he has been working for this company for a number of years. He dreams of being able to renovate his house, which was affected by the earthquake. For the time being, his family is living in poor conditions; he needs a loan to buy construction materials.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy construction materials

loans.name: Manos Juntas Rumichaca Alta Group

texts.es:
Vilma, tiene 32 años, es conviviente, tiene  cuatro hijos y es natural D. la Ciudad D. Urubamba departamento del Cusco. 

“Vilma es fundadora del banco comunal Manos Juntas D. Rumichaca D. la Unidad D. Micro finanzas D. la  Asociación Arariwa”.

Vilma nos cuenta. - En mi banco comunal “Manos Juntas D. Rumichaca”  somos 12 integrantes (9 mujeres y 3 varones), fui elegida como la presidenta y las reuniones  son cada treinta días en mi casa y en esta oportunidad  me eligieron a mí como representante del banco comunal para dar mi testimonio D. mi principal actividad económica.  

Vilma  su principal actividad económica es la elaboración D. jora, ella tiene contrata con la señora Teresa  a quien le venD. la jora. Su actividad económica complementaria es confeccionar chompas D. lana a pedido del cliente. Vilma requiere el préstamo para comprar maíz  y lana. Ya son  2  años que trabaja en el negocio y le va muy bien.
 
Vilma  permanece en el banco comunal porque quiere aprender a ser responsable con el dinero y saber invertir bien el dinero en su negocio.|

La mayoría D. los socios son comerciantes por ejemplo  algunos se dedican a la crianza D. animales menores, venta D. bebidas, venta D., comestibles, venta D. chicha D. jora y venta D. chompas y otros socios brindan servicios como por ejemplo son artistas,  empleados públicos D. la municipalidad D. Urubamba, empleado del Hotel Inti Quilla, etc. 

La ciudad D. Urubamba se encuentra a una hora y diez minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco.
texts.en:
Vilma, 32, lives with a partner and has 4 children. She is a native of the city of Urubamba, in the Cusco department. Vilma is the founder of the communal bank "Manos Juntas D. Rumichaca," which is in the Unidad Microfinanza Arariwa that is part of the larger umbrella Asociación Arariwa. Vilma tells us "in my communal bank “Manos Juntas D. Rumichaca” we have 12 members (9 women and 3 men.) I was elected president, and the group meets every 30 days in my house. This time they chose me as the representative of the bank to give my testimony of my principal economic activity." Vilma's main economic activity is making chicha D. jora (a traditional Peruvian beverage maD. from roasted corn.) She has a contract with Señora Teresa to whom she sells the jora. She also makes woolen jackets to order for her customers. Vilma needs a loan to buy corn and firewood. She has already worked for 2 years in this business, and it is going very well. Vilma belongs to the communal bank because she wants to learn how to be responsible with money and to invest well in her business. The majority of the other members are merchants, for example: some are engaged in raising young livestock, others sell drinks, food, chicha D. jora, jackets, and other members proviD. services, such as: artists, employees of the municipality of Urubamba, employees of the Hotel Inti Quilla, etc. The city of Urubamba is located an hour and 10 minutes from the city of Cusco.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vilma needs a loan to buy firewood and corn

loans.name: Jhon Henrri

texts.es: Jhon se didica al transporte de pasajeros en mototaxi propia, adquirida con sus ahorros y con prestamos financieros a traves de terceros vive en casa propia de madera con su conyuge y sus 2 hijos en edad escolar su conyuge trabaja para el programa a trabajar urbano en la tinguiña sin embargo no cuenta con documentación de ello por lo que no se le esta considerando ingresos, requiere el credito para empliar su vivienda con una nueva  habitación y poder poner una pequeña bodega ya que por la zona hay muy pocas y estan bastante alejadas. cuenta con acumulacion de bienes y con capacidad de pago para asumir el presente credito.
texts.en:
Jhon provides passenger transportation services with his own mototaxi (light, 3-wheeled passenger vehicle.) He acquired this vehicle by borrowing a third of the amount, and paying the rest with his savings. He lives in his own home, made of wood, with his spouse and their 2 school-aged children. His wife works for a public works project in Tinguiña. However, she does not have documentation from this job, and so her income is not considered.
