He needs the loan to expand his home with a new room so that he can set up a small store, since in this area there are very few stores and they are far apart. He has personal property to use for collateral, and has been judged to have sufficient income to take on the current loan.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to expand his house

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Les six  femmes du groupe Sabali (4 mariées  et 2 veuves) ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 4 enfants et  vivent  la plupart dans des  familles polygames à OUAYERMA I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur septième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes excellent  dans  le domaine de l’alimentaire  tels  la restauration avec Maïmouna  S.,  de l’achat vente  des ignames, du bois de chauffe etc.
Maïmouna S.  compte acheter avec son  prêt, 200kg de riz  + 5paquets de condiments + 2 petits ruminants + 1 chargement de charrette en bois de chauffe pour faire la restauration.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché et dans les villages voisins .
Les plats sont vendus au  grand marché de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités
texts.en:
The six women of the Sabali group (four are married and two are widows) are on average 40 years old with four children. Most live in polygamous families in OUAYERMA I, one of the boroughs of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their 7th collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs. All past loans have been repaid in full. This group of women excels in domains related to food such as the trading of yams, of firewood, or like Maïmouna S. in the restaurant business. Maïmouna S. wants to use her loan to buy 200 kilos of rice, five packages of food condiments, two small ruminants, and one cartload of firewood, to prepare meals. She gets her supplies from the main market and villages in the vicinity. The meals are sold by family members in Sikasso’s main market, for cash to both men and women customers. She is hoping to attain an average monthly income of 27,000 FCFA of which part will be used to assist her husband with daily expenditures and the remainder reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients to prepare meals

loans.name: Diciples Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Comfort A. is  a mother of 4 and married to a junior high school teacher. Comfort sells smoked fish, grass cutters and antelope meat at the bush meat market near Sunyani and has been in this business for the past 7 years. Until last year she singlehandedly paid the bills of the home including children's school fees when her husband decided to further his education. 

Comfort is required to  pre-finance hunters who supply her with the bush meat in the form of bullets so they do not give their catch to other traders. Raising enough money for this has always been her worry, hence her desire for this loan.

Comfort is the leader of 'Disciples trust bank' which has been in existence for 3 years. The group which has a membership of 6 ply their trade in the same market and as result know and trust each other. Comfort was elected leader due to her soft-heartedness and has been able to bind the group together over the years. The group hopes to use this loan to pay for goods that they would have bought on credit  at a higher price.

loans.use: Purchase bush meat (antelope) and smoked fish

loans.name: Yankadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Yankadi, toutes mariées,  ont une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans,  4 enfants et vivent  dans des  familles polygames à Mancourani II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et tous les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce  d’articles divers  tels les condiments alimentaires (avec Dialia Traoré), les brochettes de bœufs, de la pomme de terre  etc.
Dialia Traoré compte acheter avec son  prêt,  5 paquets de condiments ( tels que de l’oignon, de la tomate, du sel de cuisine, de laurier, des légumes ...).
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché et  dans les villages avoisinants .
Les condiments sont vendus au  marché de Mancourani et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Yankadi group are all married and are on average 42 years old with four children. They live in polygamous families in Mancourani II, one of the boroughs in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their 6th collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. All past loans have been repaid in full. This group of women retails various food products such as beef kebabs, potatoes, or food condiments like Dialia Traoré. Dialia Traoré wants to use her loan to buy five packages of condiments such as onions, tomatoes, kitchen salt, bay leaves, vegetables, … She gets her supplies from the main market and villages in the vicinity. The condiments are then sold in the Mancourani market and through home delivery, for cash and often for credit, mainly to women customers. She is hoping to attain an average monthly income of 18,500 FCFA of which part will be used for family expenses and the remainder reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Soro Yiriwa. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa, toutes  mariées, ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des  familles polygames à Bougoula  Ville, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce tels les légumes (choux, carottes, aubergine) à l’image de Koura O., les pagnes wax etc..
Koura O. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  20 paniers de légumes 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Médine à Sikasso et  dans les vergers des villages voisins. Les légumes sont revendus au grand marché  de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses familiales et les évènements sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four women in the Soro Yiriwa group are all married and are on average 40 years old with four children. They live in polygamous families in Bougoula Ville, one of the boroughs in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their 6th collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs. All past loans have been repaid in full. This group of women is in the retail business. For some it is selling pagnes wax (variety of colourful West-African clothing fabric), for others it is selling vegetables (cabbages, carrots, eggplants) like Koura O.. Koura O. wants to use her loan to buy 20 baskets of vegetables. She gets her supplies from the main Médina market in Sikasso and from orchards in neighbouring villages. The vegetables are then resold at the main market in Sikasso and through home delivery, for cash, to both men and women customers. She is hoping to attain an average monthly income of 17,500 FCFA of which part will be used for family expenses and social events, and the remainder reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame  Aminata  Touré  est âgée de 44 ans,  veuve  et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit  dans le domicile de son feu mari avec ses enfants au quartier Bougoufiè de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Aminata a abandonné l’école en classe de 9ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour se marier par volonté parentale. Elle commença le commerce suite au décès  de son mari. Elle débuta par la vente de gâteau, ce commerce lui a permis de comprendre les règles du commerce et de savoir faire le marketing de ses produits. Après ce fut le commerce de l’ail et d’échalotes, qu’elle mène depuis maintenant 17 ans au marché château. Elle est très connue dans ce créneau et jouit d’une grande notoriété. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin de réaliser beaucoup de bénéfice,  elle a fait recours à  Soro Yiriwaso, elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 36 mois après 2 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous bien remboursés. 
Elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 1 tonne  d’échalotes. Elle s’approvisionne  au Burkina Faso et vend au comptant, en gros et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui servira de se prendre en charge (achat de nourriture, habillement des enfants et paiement des frais de scolarité).
Son ambition est de transformer sa maison du banco en dure.
texts.en:
Aminata Toure, aged 44, is widow and mother of three children. She lives in the house of her late husband with her children in the neighborhood Bougoufié Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Aminata dropped out of school in the 9th grade (Basic Malian educational system) to get married by parental will. She started her business after the death of her husband. She began by selling cakes; this business has given her the chance to gain business and marketing expertise. Later she started selling garlic and shallots and she has been now for 17 years in this business. She is well known in the area and enjoys a good reputation. In order to increase her capital and her revenue, 36 months ago she has joined Soro Yiriwaso and she received 2 group loans and 2 individual loans, all fully repaid. She is now receving her third individual loan, that she intends to use to buy a ton of shallots. She buys and sells in Burkina Faso in cash, wholesale and credit to a clientele of men and women. With this loan she plans to earn a monthly income of 120,000 CFA francs, that she will use for the family needs (buy food, clothing for children and payment of tuition fees). Her ambition is to transform her house from adobe to something hard.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es:
Rosa, vive con sus hijos de los cuales uno se encuentra en edad 
escolar. Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa ya iniciando el negocio hace 4 años, con 
capital propio producto de ahorros. Ella posee muchos clientes en donde la mayoría son 
trabajadores de los fundos de la zona, a los cuales les brinda además de una buena 
calidad de sus mercadería buenos precios, por este motivo es que los clientes en forma 
mensual le solicitan la mercadería, sus sueños de Rosa son incrementar su negocio y 
así tener mayores ingresos, ya que esto hará que mejore sus condiciones de vida y 
pueda reconstruir su vivienda.
texts.en:
Rosa lives with her children, one of whom is school age. She makes a living selling clothes at a business she started four years ago with money she had saved. She has many customers, the majority of whom are workers from around the area, and she provides them with high-quality merchandise with good prices as well. For this reason, clients request new merchandise monthly. Rosa's dreams are to expand her business and thus increase her profits since that will improve her quality of life and she can rebuild her home.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Fatoumata Yeya

texts.fr:
Madame   Fatoumata Yeya Traoré    est âgée de 32 ans, mariée et mère 4 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari avec ses enfants dans une famille nucléaire  au  quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Matrone de formation et de carrière, elle commença le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à côté de cette dernière depuis son bas âge (en marge de ses études et de sa  profession), elle est nantie d’une forte expérience. Alors elle  a décidé d’évoluer en solo en menant   des activités génératrices de revenus telles la vente d’habits, de chaussures et de glace alimentaire depuis 2 ans et  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. Sa force de vente est la masse de sa glace qui est grande et grosse.  
 Dans le dessein de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, elle est  à son 1er  prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser  pour acheter, 1  congélateur   sur place à Ségou. Madame Fatoumata Yeya Traoré  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  essentiellement d’hommes qui sont des boulangers.  
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 40 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permettra de subvenir à certaines de ses charges (habillement, savons et médicaments). 
Son ambition est  de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Yeya Traoré is 32 years old, married and the mother of four children. She lives with her husband and children as a nuclear family in the Hamdallaye district of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). She is educated as a traditional birth attendant, and started her business activity with her mother who used to sell condiments. After several years of learning this business from an early age (parallel to her studies and her regular work), she has amassed solid experience. This is when she decided to launch a solo business selling clothing, shoes and food-grade ice, which she has been doing for two years. Her business is popular and she has a large customer base. Her strength is a large stock of ice. In order to better satisfy customer demand and increase net profits, she has turned to Soro Yiriwaso. This would be her first individual loan which she plans to use for purchasing a freezer for her home in Ségou. Mrs. Fatoumata Yeya Traoré sells for cash and on credit to a customer based composed mainly of men who are bakers. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 40,000 West African Francs, which will allow her to take care of some of her needs (clothing, toiletries and medications). Her goal is to be able to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a freezer

loans.name: Kadidia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadidia  M.  est âgée de 51 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari avec ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle avec 2 autres coépouses  au  quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait l’école et issue d’une famille de commerçants, elle commença très tôt le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des  poissons. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à côté de cette dernière jusqu’à son mariage, elle décide d’évoluer seule en menant le commerce de jus de fruits et de glace. 
Elle  mène cette  activité  depuis  maintenant 10 ans et  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. 
Dans le dessein de renforcer ses capacités de production, elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso, elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 30 mois, après 5 prêts solidaires tous  bien remboursés. 
Elle est à son 1er  prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, 2 congélateurs. Elle s’approvisionne en République Islamique de Mauritanie. Madame Kadidia  M.  vend ses jus et glace au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 75 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permettra de subvenir à certaines de ses charges (habillement, savons et médicaments).
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadidia M. is 51 years old, married and the mother of four children. She lives at her husband’s place with her children in a traditional family with two other co-spouses. They live in the neighborhood of Hamdallaye in Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She did not attend school and came from a family of retailers. She started very early in the business with her mother who sold fish. After several years of apprenticeship next to her mother and until her wedding, she decided to develop by herself by conducting a business of fruit juices and ice cream. She has been in this business for 10 years now and enjoys a large customer base and notoriety. With the intention to strengthen her production ability she appealed to Soro Yiriwaso. She has had this relationship for the last 30 months, after 5 group loans all fully reimbursed. This is her first individual loan and she would like to use it to buy 2 freezers. She buys her supplies in the Islamic Republic of Mauritania. Mrs. Kadidia M. sells her juices and ice cream for cash or on credit to customers made up of women and men. She is planning on making a monthly profit of 75,000 Francs CFA, which will allow her to provide for some of her expenses (clothing, soap, medications).

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of freezers

loans.name: Halima

texts.fr:
Halima M.   est âgée de 30 ans, célibataire et mère 2 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son père  avec ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle avec plusieurs autres personnes  au  quartier Bamanan de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait l’école et issue d’une famille de commerçants, elle commença très tôt le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des habits et ustensiles de cuisines. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à côté de cette dernière et ayant bien maîtrisé les rouages du commerce, elle décide d’évoluer seule pour mener plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus bien avant  de se reconvertir dans le commerce des habits et de couvertures draps. Elle  mène cette  activité  depuis 5 ans et  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. Sa force de vente est la qualité de ses habits qui sont des importations.
 Dans le but de faire face à sa demande clientèle, elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso, elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 12 mois, après  un 1er  prêt     bien remboursé. 
Elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 1 balle  de bazins riches et  5 couvertures draps. 
Elle s’approvisionne en drap au Burkina Faso et pour les bazins au Sénégal.  Halima M.    vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 75 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permettra de subvenir à certaines de ses charges (habillement, savons et médicaments).
texts.en:
Mrs. Halima M. is 30 years old, single and the mother of two children. She lives at her father’s with her children in a traditional family with several other persons. They live in the neighborhood of Bamanan in Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali) She did not attend school and came from a family of retailers. She started very early in the business beside her mother who sold clothing and kitchen utensils. After several years of apprenticeship next to her mother and having mastered the tricks of the trade, she decided to develop by herself and conducted several income-generating activities. She then converted to the retail of clothing and covering sheets. She has been in this business for five years now and enjoys a large customer base and notoriety. Her strong sales are due to the quality of her clothing that is imported. In order to meet her customers’ demand she turned to Soro Yiriwaso, which she has had an association for the last 12 months. After 1 loan fully reimbursed, this is her second individual loan and she would like to use it to buy 1 bale of damask cloth and 5 covering sheets. She buys her sheets in Burkina Faso and the damask in Senegal. Halima Maiga sells for cash or on credit to customers composed of women and men. She is planning on making a monthly profit of 75,000 Francs CFA, which will allow her to provide for some of her expenses (clothing, soaps, medications).

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cothing

loans.name: Allah Kan Dèmè Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Allah Kan Dèmè est composé de cinq femmes toutes mariées dans des familles polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans, 6 enfants et habitent  toutes  à Sakoïba (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et d’appartenance à une même association  traditionnelle d’entraide  des femmes du village. 
Les membres du groupe achètent et revendent essentiellement du bois de chauffe, du charbon de bois et des céréales telles l’arachide.
 Le besoin d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce les a motivé à collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Après six prêts tous correctement remboursés, elles sont à leur 7ème  prêt solidaire et Madame Maïmouna C. qui est un des membres évoluant dans l’alimentaire compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 7sacs d’arachide en gousse. Elle s’approvisionne à Sakoïba et dans les villages environnants. Elle décortique son arachide, le trie,  le grille et le débarrasse de sa pluche. Elle revend à domicile et à la foire de  Ségou au comptant et à  crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes transformatrices d’arachide en pâte. 
Madame Maïmouna espère  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser son prêt, contribuer à  certaines dépenses familiales et participer aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, funérailles).  
Son ambition est de pérenniser son petit commerce et aider son ménage à acheter des animaux de traits.
texts.en:
The Allah Kan Dèmè group is comprised of five women, all married in polygamous families. They are 46 years old on average and have six children, all of them living in Sakoïba (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other through family and marriage ties, as well as belonging to the same traditional women's aid association in the village. The group members buy and sell mostly firewood, charcoal, and grains such as peanuts. The need to increase their working capital motivated them to work with Soro Yiriwaso. After six fully repaid loans, they are on their seventh group loan. Mrs. Maïmouna C., one of the group members working with food, plans to use her loan to buy seven bags of unshelled peanuts. She gets her supplies in Sakoïba and surrounding villages. She shells the peanuts, sorts them, grills them and peels them. She sells them from home and at the Ségou market, for cash and on credit, generally to women who transform the peanuts into paste. Mrs. Maïmouna hopes to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay back her loan, contribute to certain family expenditures, and participate in social events (marriages, baptisms, funerals). Her goal is to maintain her small business and help her family buy draft animals.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of peanuts

loans.name: Ollantay Ii Group

texts.es:
Gregoria, tiene 35 años, es conviviente, tiene tres hijos y vive en la ciudad del Cusco. 

Gregoria nos cuenta. - En mi banco comunal “Ollantay II”  somos 13 integrantes (12 mujeres y 1 varón), la junta directiva está conformada por Juana Esther que es la presidente, Margarita que es la Tesorera, Ofelia que es la secretaria, Sofía que es la fiscal y las reuniones  son cada treinta días en la oficina central D. la Asociación Arariwa y en esta oportunidad  me eligieron a mí como representante del banco comunal para dar mi testimonio D. mi principal actividad económica.  

“Gregoria hace dos años que participa en el banco comunal Ollantay II la Unidad D. Micro finanzas D. la  Asociación Arariwa”.

Gregoria su principal actividad económica es la venta y compra D. papa pelada para las pollerías y restaurante, Gregorio requiere el préstamo para comprar papa. Ya son  5  años que trabaja en el negocio y le va muy bien. Su sueño D. la socia es tener su propia casa y sacar profesionales a sus hijos. 

La mayoría D. los socios son comerciantes por ejemplo  algunos se dedican a la bisutería, venta D. frutas, venta papa pelada,  venta D. comestibles, venta D. abarrotes, venta D. artesanía y otros socios brindan servicios como por ejemplo D. cobrador D. pasajes, profesora, etc. La mayoría D. los socios son puntuales y responsables con las cuotas.
texts.en:
Gregoria is 35 years old and lives with her partner and her three children in the city of Cusco. She tells us, "In my community bank 'Ollantay II', there are 13 members (12 women and one man), and the board of directors consists of Juana Esther as president, Magarita as the treasurer, Ofelia as the secretary, and Sofia as the finance advisor. The meetings are every 30 days at the central office of Asociación Arariwa. In this instance they have chosen me as the representative of the community bank to give my testimonial about my principal economic activity." Gregoria has been with the community bank for two years and she makes a living buying potatoes and selling them peeled to poultry shops and restaurants. She is requesting the loan to purchase potatoes. She has had the business for five years and it is going very well. Her dream is to have her own home and see her children become professionals. The majority of the community banks members are merchants. For example, some make a living in jewelry, others sell fruits, meals, groceries or craftwork, while others proviD. services as a parts collector, teacher, etc. The majority of the members are punctual and responsible with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase potatoes and other products

loans.name: Fuerza Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Fuerza inicia su segundo ciclo con 17 socias. 
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de comidas, abarrotes en general, gelatinas, lácteos, artesanía, frutas y quesos.
Como es el caso de la Señora Alicia que es la presidenta del Banco Comunal, Alicia es soltera, tiene 29 años y 2 hijos, anteriormente Alicia vendía artesanía y por problemas familiares dejo de realizar este negocio, hace 3 años implemento una tienda de abarrotes en su casa y poco a poco fue agregando mas productos en su negocio ahora vende verduras, frutas. Además los días domingos vende frutas y bebidas en la feria de animales de la ciudad, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su hija mayor. Alicia invertirá su negocio en la compra de arroz, leche, azúcar. Los sueños de Alicia son tener una tienda grande y construir su casa de material noble. 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 300 soles, 500 soles, 600 soles haciendo un total de 6,600 soles.
texts.en:
The Fuerza Community Bank is starting its second loan cycle with 17 members. The members have different businesses like selling food, groceries, jellies, milk products, crafts, fruit or cheeses. Alicia is the president of the community bank. She is a 29-year-old single mother of two children. Previously she sold craftwork but because of family problems she had to give up the business. Three years ago she set up a grocery stO. in her home and little by little she added mO. products to the business. Now she sells fruits and vegetables. FurthermO., on Sundays she sells fruits and beverages at the city's animal trade fair, which she does with the help of her eldest daughter. Alicia plans to invest in her business by purchasing rice, milk and sugar. Her dreams are to have a big stO. and to build a home out of quality material. The members require different loan amounts, such as 300, 500 and 600 soles, for a grand total of 6,600 soles.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar and milk along with other products

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi comprend sept femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames, avec en moyenne de 42 ans, 5 enfants et habitant  toutes  à Sakoïbougouni, un village de la Commune Rurale de Sakoïba (4ème Région administrative du Mali) .
Les membres du groupe font essentiellement le commerce du bois de chauffe, du charbon de bois, des condiments alimentaires, du savon et de la restauration.  
Le besoin d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les motiva à s’organiser et à intégrer le programme  crédit avec qui elles sont à leur 3ème prêt solidaire. 
Quant à l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, Madame Arahama Traoré compte utiliser le sien pour acheter,  5 sacs de graines de Néré. Elle s’approvisionne à  Kouri et à Ségou. 
Pour transformer les graines de Néré en Sounbala, elle les trie les fait bouillir pendant longtemps, les pile légèrement,  les débarrasse de tous les  déchets, les fait fumer à la vapeur puis, les garder hermétiquement fermé dans un vase pendant au moins deux jours avant de les écraser, les mettre en boule et les faire sécher. Son Sounbala est beaucoup apprécié par sa clientèle. 
Elle revend à domicile, en ambulant à travers le village et à la foire de  Ségou. La vente se fait au comptant et à  crédit à une clientèle essentiellement composée  de femmes. 
Arahama espère  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 17.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, contribuer à  certaines dépenses familiales, participer aux évènements sociaux. Son ambition est d’acheter une charrette et un âne pour faciliter son transport et celui des marchandises.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi is composed of seven married women mostly in polygamous families.  These women average 42 years of age and five children all living in Sakoïbougouni, a village of the rural community of Sakoïba (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They essentially do commerce involving firewood, charcoal, condiments, soaps, and food catering.    Needing to increase their working capital, the group members were motivated to become organized and to join the loan program.  They are now on their third solidarity loan.  As for the use of the loan, Ms. Arahama Traoré plans on using hers to buy five sacks of néré seeds.  She gets her supplies in Kouri and in Ségou.  To process the néré seeds into sounbala, she sorts them, boils them for a long time, pounds them lightly, removes all the waste, steam-cooks the seeds, and then keeps them sealed in a container for at least two days.  Then she crushes them, puts them into a bowl, and dries them.  Her sounbala is much appreciated by her customers.  Arahama sells out of her home, door-to-door, and at the Ségou fair.  Sales are made, cash or credit accepted, to a customer base composed essentially of women.  Arahama hopes to make a monthly profit of 17,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to help cover certain family expenses, and to take part in societal events.  Her ambition is to buy a cart and donkey to facilitate transport for herself and the merchandise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying néré seeds

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
This 31-year-old was a business intermediary before he began his small retail business in Bugoba in Mukono. His business now has a longevity span of five years.

W. Moses’ winning calling card during the course of these five years has been his resilience and courage in the face of financial difficulties. With this he has built on his experience, an experience that has played into his hands.

Having gone through this trivial-round mill, Moses is now taking a long view. He is looking at going into a wholesale business. He is widely optimistic on the basis of the 528,300 shillings he makes a month and the fact that he is also applying for this loan. With other businesses like the kiosk and video hall he operates, Moses anticipates his savings will grow.

The purchase of rice and dried beans for his shop is what he is planning to do with this loan money. His three children are all in school and he is happily married.

loans.use: To purchase bags of dried beans and rice for his business

loans.name: Djantoyerela Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Djantoyerela sont mariées en majorité dans des familles polygames. Elles ont en moyenne  47 ans, 6 enfants et habitent  toutes  à Sakoïba, chef lieu de la Commune Rurale de Sakoïba (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
 Les membres du groupe font le commerce d’articles divers avec l’achat vente du bois de chauffe, des céréales et des habits. 
Le besoin d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, incita  ces femmes du groupe Djantoyerela à collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur  7ème prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les six précédents. 
Madame Salimata C. la présidente du groupe fait le commerce de bois  de chauffe depuis sa jeunesse. 
Elle commence juste après les récoltes à constituer un stock de bois en allant chercher elle-même du bois mort sur leur terroir. C’est au cours du second trimestre de l’année qu’elle commença à acheter du bois pour y ajouter au stock existant. 
Salimata compte  utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 8  chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne sur place à Sakoïba avec les exploitants agrées et effectue ses ventes à Ségou,  en ambulant à travers les quartiers de la ville  généralement au comptant et à  crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de  femmes.  
Madame Salimata espère  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, contribuer à l’achat de condiments, du savon, du pétrole, de fournitures scolaires et des habits pour les élèves et participer aux évènements sociaux 
Son ambition est d’avoir une 2ème charrette avec âne lui permettant d’être plus indépendante dans le transport au niveau de  son activité.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Djantoyerela are married in polygamous families.  These women average 47 years of age and six children all living in Sakoïba, the seat of the rural community of Sakoïba (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They do commerce in a variety of goods, buying and selling firewood, grains, and clothing. Needing to increase their working capital, the group members were motivated to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their seventh solidarity loan after having properly repaid the six preceding ones.  Ms. Salimata C., the group's president, does commerce in firewood by going herself to look for dead wood on their land.  In this year's second trimester, she started to buy wood to add to an existing stock.  She plans on using her loan for buying eight chart loads of firewood.  She gets her supplies locally in Sakoïba from approved producers.  She sells in Ségou by going door-to-door in the district of the city. And she accepts cash in general and credit from a customer base composed of women and men.  Ms. Salimata hopes to make a monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay her loan, to help with buying condiments, soaps, fuel, and school supplies and clothing for the children, and to take part in societal events.  Her ambition is to obtain a second cart and donkey enabling her to be more independent with regard to business transportation.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying firewood

loans.name: Aba Pa Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Agartha K. calls herself a humble and honest petty trader who sells all kinds of fruit, vegetables and other foodstuffs. She has been in this business for the past 20 years and has been able to support her family with the proceeds from her business. As a result of her honesty she buys from farmers on credit and pays back only after she has sold everything. She says this comes with a cost since she has to pay more than the normal price for items sold to her on credit. 

Agartha hopes to own her own store in Sunyani township where she will sell a variety of food items and has been working towards this goal over the years. She also has the dream of supporting her children's education to a level where they will be gainfully employed.

Aba Pa in our local language means a "good seed" and for Agartha and colleagues, whatever loan they receive from lenders is a good seed sown in their business. They hope that this good seed will enable them to attain the dream of expanding their business to the desired level. This group of 10 has been together for a year and hope to maintain forever the unity cord that brought them together.

loans.use: Tomatoes, mangoes, cassava and plantains

loans.name: Djiguissèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djiguissèmè sont toutes mariées dans des familles monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent le quartier Bagadadji de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues dans le camp militaire à travers des relations de service (leurs maris sont des militaires) et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le marché Médine Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font le commerce de chaussures, savons, portes monnaie, parures (bracelets, boucles d’oreilles et colliers), pommades et sucres. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 10ème  prêt solidaire. 
Madame Safiatou Djourté veut utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 300 paires de chaussures pour hommes.  
Elle se ravitaille en gros à Bamako et la revend  à domicile dans une boutique située au bord du goudron à Sébougou à une clientèle composée essentiellement d’hommes. 
Madame Safiatou Djourté espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour réinvestir dans son activité et épargner afin d’avoir un véhicule pour le transport.
texts.en:
The members of the group Djiguissèmè are all married in monogamous families.  These women average 35 years of age and five children living in the Bagadadji district of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through service ties (their husbands are soldiers) and through income-generating businesses at the market of Médine Ségou. They do commerce in shoes, soaps, wallets, fine accessories (bracelets, earrings, necklaces), ointments, and sugar.  Concerned about increasing their working capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 10th solidarity loan. Ms. Safiatou Djourté wants to use her loan for buying 300 pairs of men's shoes.  She gets her supplies wholesale in Bamako (capital of Mali) and sells out of her home to a customer base composed essentially of men.  She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and for savings to obtain a vehicle for transport.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying shoes

loans.name: Libertad Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Libertad inicia su séptimo ciclo con 17 socias. 
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. ropa, frutas, comida, lencería, juguetes, mercería, miel D. abeja y artesanías.
Como es el caso D. la Señora Odilia que es la presidenta del Banco Comunal, Odilia es casada, tiene 63 años y 3 hijos, Odilia venD. miel D. abeja que compra en los diferentes pueblos D. la región, sus ventas los realiza en instituciones y mercados. Además Odilia venD. ropas interiores que ofrece a diferentes clientes. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. miel. Los sueños D. Odilia son mejorar su negocio y que su ultima hija culmine sus estudios D. Contabilidad. 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 450 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles haciendo un total D. 13,600 soles.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Libertad” (Freedom) is starting its seventh loan cycle with 17 members. They engage in different businesses selling clothing, fruit, food, lingerie, toys, sewing supplies, honey, and handicrafts.

Such is the case with Sra. Odilia, the Communal Bank president. Odilia is 63 years old, married, and has three children. She sells honey that she acquires from different villages in the region. Her products are sold to institutions and markets. In addition, she sells undergarments to different customers. Her loan will be invested in the purchase of honey. Odilia dreams of improving her business and seeing her youngest daughter finish her degree in accounting.

The members need different loan amounts ranging from 450 PEN, 600 PEN, to 900 PEN, for a grand total of 13,600 PEN to the entire Communal Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase honey

loans.name: Yansy Marcela

texts.es: Yansy Marcela B. R., tiene la edad de 28 años, está soltera y vive con su hijo de 8 años. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de inventario para su negocio. Desea tener un inventario más amplio y variado de productos para ofrecer en su pulpería. Tiene varios años de haber empezado con este negocio, y cuenta con muy buenos clientes, por eso ve la necesidad de ofrecer mayor variedad de productos en el negocio, además de aportar mayores ingresos para su economía. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy agradecida con las facilidades que se le han brindado siempre. Ella espera en un futuro tener una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como comerciante.
texts.en:
Yansy Marcela B. R. is 28 years old, single, and lives with her 8 year old son. This loan will be used to purchase inventory for her business. She wants to have a larger stock and wider variety of products to offer in her store. Yansy started this business several years ago and has very good customers. She needs to offer a better variety of products in her business so that she can generate more income to support herself financially. This is her first loan with FUDECOSUR and she is very happy with the services that have been provided. She hopes in the future to have a better quality life and greater financial stability. In addition, she wants to continue growing as a person and as a businesswoman.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase inventory for her business

loans.name: Galabou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Galabou est composé de neuf femmes mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent  toutes  à Sakoïbougouni, village de la Commune Rurale de Sakoïba (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Les membres du groupe font le commerce  de vermicelle, de céréales, de calebasses, du bois de chauffe et de l’embouche ovine. 
Le besoin d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les motiva à s’organiser et à intégrer le programme  avec qui elles sont à leur 3ème prêt solidaire. 
Madame Menta Traoré, un membre du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 2 sacs de farine de blé qu’elle transformera à l’aide d’une machine manuelle en vermicelle à vendre. 
Elle s’approvisionne à  Ségou sur place auprès des  commerçants grossistes. 
Pour faire du vermicelle elle pétrit une quantité suffisante avec de l’eau propre jusqu’à obtenir une pâte homogène et fine qu’elle fait passer à la machine puis la fait sécher.  
Elle revend son vermicelle à domicile, en ambulant à travers les villages voisins. La vente se fait au comptant et à  crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Menta compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 19.500FCFA à l’image des autres femmes qui sera utilisé pour, contribuer à certaines dépenses familiales et augmenter son fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The group Galabou is composed of nine married women in large traditional families.  The women average 37 years of age and four children all living in Sakoïbougouni, a village of the rural community of Sakoïba (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do commerce in vermicelli, grains, calabashes, and firewood, and they raise sheep. Needing to increase their working capital, the group members were motivated to become organized and to join the program. They are now on their third solidarity loan.  Ms. Menta Traoré, a member of the group, plans on using her loan for buying two sacks of wheat flour that she will process into vermacelli by using a manual machine.  She gets her supplies in Ségou locally from wholesale merchants.  To make vermicelli, she kneads a large enough amount with clean water to make a nice uniform dough, which she puts through the machine and then dries. She sells her vermicelli out of her home and door-to-door in neighboring villages.  Accepting cash and credit, she sells to a customer base composed of women and men.  Menta plans on making a monthly profit of 19,500 francs CFA, like the other women. The profit will be for helping to cover certain family expenses and increasing her working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying wheat flour

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouman est composé majoritairement de femmes célibataires ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans, 4 enfants et habitant toutes le quartier Darsalam de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles  se sont connues à travers des liens de  voisinage et de leurs activités de petit commerce dans le marché Médine. 
Elles font le commerce, de mangues, de riz, d’habits pour enfants et de bazins. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 5ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre précédents.
Mademoiselle Bah Mallé qui fait de l’habillement  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 5 douzaines d’habits  pour enfants. 
Elle se ravitaille en habits en gros à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et  revend à domicile et en ambulant dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Mademoiselle Bah Mallé espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  être réinvesti dans son activité et acheter petit à petit les matériels pour son trousseau de mariage.
texts.en:
The group Sabougnouman is composed mostly of unmarried women who average 30 years of age and four children all living in the Darsalam district of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through community ties and their small-scale businesses at the Médine market.  They do commerce in mangoes, rice,  children's clothing, and damask fabrics.  Concerned about increasing their working capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their fifth solidarity loan after having properly repaid the four preceding ones. Ms. Bah Mallé, who works in clothing, plans on using her loan for buying five dozen pieces of children's clothing.  She gets her stock of clothing wholesale in Bamako (capital of Mali) and resells out of her home and door-to-door through the districts to a customer base of women and men. She hopes to make a monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in the business and buying little by little the items for her hope chest. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothing

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouman est composé de quatre femmes toutes mariées dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne de 29 ans, 3 enfants et habitent toutes   Sakoïbougouni, village situé dans la Commune Rurale de Sakoïba  (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
 Les membres du groupe achètent et revendent du bois de chauffe, du charbon de bois, de la pâte d’arachide et font de la restauration. 
Ces femmes du groupe Sabougnouman sont à leur 1er  prêt de groupe avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Madame Djeneba B. mène l’achat et la vente du charbon de bois depuis des années. 
Elle utilisera son montant pour acheter, 15 sacs de charbon de bois et une douzaine de sacs vide pour l’emballage du charbon. 
Elle s’approvisionne sur place à Sakoïbougouni. Elle  revend son charbon à Ségou au comptant et à  crédit  à une  clientèle composée d’hommes dont la plupart  sont des blanchisseurs de la place et des femmes. 
Madame Djeneba B. espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser son prêt et contribuer pour le complément de prix de condiments.
texts.en:
The Sabougnouman group is composed of four women, all married and living in monogamous families. On the average, they are 29 years old and have three children; all of them live in Sakoïbougouni, a village in the rural community of Sakoïba (the 4th administrative district of Mali). The group members buy and resell firewood, charcoal, peanut paste and also prepare food for sale. This would be the first loan with Soro Yriiwaso for Sabougnouman group. Mrs. Djeneba Malo has been in business resells charcoal for year. She will use her part of the loan to purchase 15 bags of charcoal and a dozen of empty bags to repackage charcoal. She purchases her stock locally in Sakoïbougouni. She resells her charcoal in Ségou, for cash and in credit to a customer based composed of men (mostly local laundrymen) as well as women. Mrs. Djeneba B. hopes to acheive a monthly income of 15,000 West African Francs, which will be used to repaid her loan and used towards the pruchase of condiments.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing charcoal [for resale]

loans.name: Tientigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tientigui est constitué de femmes mariées vivant dans des familles monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier Darsalam de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et mariage.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce, de fourrage (aliment bétail), de tomate, d’habits pour enfants et de calebasses. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 4ème  prêt solidaire.
Madame Mariam Traoré  qui fait l’achat vente d’articles décoratifs compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 200 calebasses. Elle se ravitaille en calebasse à Tona et à Konodimini. 
Les calebasses sont épluchées et gravées de petites figures ou dessins avec des matériels conçus traditionnellement pour la circonstance. 
Elles sont revendues sur commande aux nouveaux mariés et en ambulant parfois dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame  Mariam Traoré à l’image des autres membres du groupe espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27 500FCFA qui sera réinvesti dans leurs activités et épargner.
texts.en:
The Tientigui group is made up of married women who live in monogamous families. They average 39 years of age and have an average of five children each. They all live in the Darsalam district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and met through neighbours and marriage. This group of women trade in fodder (food for livestock), tomatoes, children's clothing and calabashes (vines which can be dried out to be used as bottles or utensils). With a view to increase their businesses, they decided to work together with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their fourth group loan. Mrs. Mariam Traoré who buys and sells decorative articles is planning to use her loan to buy 200 calabashes. She gets her supply of calabashes in Tona and Konodimini. The calabashes are peeled and engraved with small figures or designs made out materials which have been traditionally designed for this purpose. They are resold to order to newly married couples, sometimes on a door-to-door basis in the various neighborhoods, and the customer base is made up of women and men. Mrs. Mariam Traoré hopes, along with the other members of the group, to make an average monthly profit of 27,500FCFA part of which will be invested in their businesses and part for their savings.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase calabashes

loans.name: Chiara Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Chiara inicia su séptimo ciclo con 18 socias. Las socias son del Distrito D. Chiara que se encuentra a 30 minutos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. animales menores, lácteos, abarrotes en general, cereales, quesos y la agricultura.
Como es el caso D. la Señora Rosa que es fiscal D. su Banco Comunal, Rosa es soltera y tiene 26 años, vive con sus padres, Rosa viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región en donD. compra cereales los cuales comercializa en los mercado D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho. Además Rosa compra animales que venD. en la feria D. animales D. la ciudad. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. cereales. Los sueños D. Rosa son construir su casa, comprar un terreno para sembrar y construir su casa en la ciudad D. Ayacucho.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 600 soles, 750 soles haciendo un total D. 12,100 soles.
texts.en:
The Chiara Communal Bank is starting its seventh loan cycle with 18 members. They are from the District of Chiara, which is located 30 minutes away from the city of Ayacucho. The members engage in different business activities that incluD. farming and selling small animals, dairy products, groceries, grain, and cheeses.

Such is the case of Sra. Rosa, who serves as the Communal Bank auditor. Rosa is 26 years old, single, and lives with her parents. She travels to different fairs in the region to buy grain and then sells it at the city market in Ayacucho. Rosa also buys animals to sell at the city animal fair. Her loan will be invested in the purchase of grain. Rosa dreams of building her own house in Ayacucho and buying a plot of land where she can plant crops.

The members need different loan amount ranging from 300 PEN, 600 PEN, to 750 PEN, for a grand total of 12,100 PEN to the entire Communal Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grain

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tièssiri est  composé de cinq femmes  mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles  élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans, 5 enfants et  habitent  toutes  à Sakoïba (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
 Les membres du groupe font  essentiellement  de la restauration et la vente du bois de chauffe qu’elles cherchent en brousse ou achètent avec les hommes. 
Le besoin d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce les incita à collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt solidaire, le précédent fut remboursé sans difficulté. 
Madame Abibatou Traoré fait de la restauration, avec les rôtis de petits ruminants. 
Elle utilisera son prêt pour acheter, 3 moutons et 4 chèvres sur place dans le village. Elle fait égorger ses animaux, dépecer puis les cuit dans les mesures d’hygiène requises  en rôtis (dans des fours traditionnels). 
Elle vend  sa viande cuite (dibissoko) à domicile et en ambulant à travers le village. la vente se fait généralement au comptant et à  crédit à une clientèle essentiellement composée d’hommes et quelques rares fois aux femmes. 
Madame Abibatou jouit d’une grande réputation dans la commune pour son activité (pratiquée généralement par les hommes) et  pense réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 22.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt et contribuer à la prise en charge de certaines dépenses familiales. 
Son ambition est l’embouche ovine et acheter  du matériel agricole afin d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans son foyer.
texts.en:
The Tièssiri group is composed of five married women who live mostly in large, traditional extended families. They are, on average, 43 years old, have five children and they all live in Sakoïba (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The members of the group are mainly involved in food preparation and the sale of firewood which they gather in the woods or buy from men. The need to increase their working capital motivated them to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their second joint loan, having repaid the first one without any difficulty. Madame Abibatou Traoré has a business of roasting meat. She will use her loan to buy three sheep and four goats in her village. She has the animals slaughtered and butchered and then cooks them according to the hygienic codes of roasting (in traditional ovens). She sells her cooked meat (dibissoko) from her home and traveling throughout her village. She generally makes her sales in cash and on credit to an essentially male clientele, and only rarely to women. Madame Abibatou enjoys an excellent reputation in the community for her work (which is generally done by men) and believes that she can clear a monthly profit of 22,500 FCFA which will be used to repay her loan and to contribute to meeting certain family responsibilities. Her ambition is to raise sheep and to buy agricultural products in order to have her own sustainable food supply at home.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy small livestock

loans.name: Henry

texts.es: Henry R. F., tiene la edad de 29 años, está casado, y vive con su esposa y sus 2 hijos de 6 y 2 años de edad, y son su mayor prioridad. El crédito lo quiere para asistir su finca, específicamente para el cultivo de café, la idea es comprar el abono y el fertilizante. Desea darle el adecuado mantenimiento al cultivo de café para lograr una mejor calidad y para obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando sea tiempo de cosecha. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Henry también trabaja desde hace varios años en la agricultura. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
Henry R. F. is 29 years old, married, and lives with his wife and two children, ages 6 and 2, who are his top priority. This loan will be used to maintain his farm, specifically for the purchase of compost and fertilizer for his coffee crop. He wants to provide proper maintenance to his coffee crop in order to achieve the best quality and the highest possible price when it is time to harvest. This is his first loan and he is very happy with the services that have been provided. Don Henry has worked several years in agriculture. In the future, he hopes to provide his family with a better quality of life and greater financial stability. Henry also wants to continue growing as a person and as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase compost & fertilizers for his coffee crop

loans.name: Orquideas Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Orquídeas inicia su ciclo 43 con 18 socias. 
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. Golosinas, comidas, abarrotes en general, panes, pasteles, cosméticos, verduras y fabricación D. ladrillos.
Como es el caso D. la Señora Asunción presidenta del Banco Comunal, Asunción es conviviente, tiene 47 años y 3 hijos, Asunción viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región en donD. venD. ropa variada, actividad que realiza 3 veces a la semana, además reparte en los negocios. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. chompas, blusas. Los sueños D. Asunción son mejorar su negocio y que su hija culmine sus estudios y sea profesional.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 450 soles, 600 soles haciendo un total D. 12,300 soles.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Orquídeas” (Orchids) is starting its 43rd loan cycle with 18 members. The members engage in different businesses selling candy, food, groceries, bread, cakes, cosmetics, vegetables, and bricks.

Such is the case with Sra. Asunción, the Communal Bank president. She is 47 years old, in a common law marriage, and has three children. Asunción travels to different fairs in the region to sell different types of clothing. She engages in this activity three times a week and devotes the rest of her time to other parts of her business. Her loan will be invested in the purchase of sweaters and blouses. Asunción dreams of improving her business and seeing her daughter finish her studies and become a professional.

The members need different loan amounts ranging from 300 PEN, 450 PEN, to 600 PEN for a grand total of 12,300 PEN to the entire Communal Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sweaters & blouses

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badenya (2 veuves et 2 mariées) vivent dans des  familles monogames avec en moyenne 48 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent  le quartier Darsalam, Commune Urbaine de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali)  et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de mariage.
 Les membres du groupe achètent et revendent des habits notamment des pagnes wax, fancy, des tissus brodés, des tissus légers, des draps de lit, des rideaux et  des sacs à main. 
Le besoin  d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce  et le désir de diversifier leurs marchandises les motivèrent à continuer à entretenir de bonnes relations avec l’institution. Elles en sont  à leur 7ème   prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursé les précédents. 
Madame Kadiatou Djiré mène l’achat et la vente d’habits depuis sept ans. Elle utilisera son montant pour acheter : 8 pièces de pagnes wax et 4 pièces de tissus légers en coton beaucoup utilisés pendant la période de chaleur. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Ségou  et  revend ses habits, à domicile et en ambulant à travers les quartiers de Darsalam, Hamdallaye et Médine au comptant et à  crédit  à une  clientèle composée  de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Kadiatou Djiré espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, contribuer à la prise en charge de certaines dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The Badenya group (two widows and two married women) live in monogamous families and are, on average, 48 years old and have three children. They all live in the Darsalem district in the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and know each other as neighbors, as friends and through marriage ties. The members of the group buy and sell clothing, pagnes (lengths of brightly colored cloth used for clothing) of the Wax and Fancy brands, embroidered fabric, lightweight fabric, bed sheets, curtains and handbags. The need to increase their working capital and the desire to diversify their merchandise has motivated them to maintain their good relationship with the institution. They are on their seventh joint loan, having properly repaid the preceding ones. Mrs. Kadiatou Djiré has been managing the purchase and sale of clothing for seven years. She will use her funds to buy eight Wax pagnes and four lengths of light cotton cloth which is very often used during the hot season. She gets her supplies at the main market in Ségou and sells her clothing from her home and traveling around the districts of Darsalam, Hamdallaye and Médine. She deals in cash and credit to a clientele of men and women. Mrs. Kadiatou Djiré hopes to clear a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA which will be used to repay her loan and to contribute to meeting certain family expenses.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: José

texts.es: José E. G., tiene la edad de 39 años, está en unión libre, y vive con su esposa y su hijo de 4 años de edad, y son su mayor prioridad. El crédito lo quiere para asistir su finca, específicamente para el cultivo de café, la idea es comprar el abono y el fertilizante. Desea darle el adecuado mantenimiento al cultivo de café para lograr una mejor calidad y para obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando sea tiempo de cosecha. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don José también trabaja desde hace muchos años en la agricultura. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
José E. G. is 39 years old and lives with his common law wife and their four year old son, who are his highest priority. This loan will be used to help maintain his farm, specifically for the purpose of growing coffee. José plans to buy compost and fertilizer so that he can adequately maintain his coffee crop. This will result in better quality and the highest possible price when it comes time to harvest. This is his first loan with FUDECOSUR and he is very happy with the services that have been provided. Don José has worked many years in agriculture. He hopes in the future to provide his family with a better quality of life and greater financial stability. In addition, he wants to continue growing as a person and as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase compost & fertilizers for his coffee crop

loans.name: Ollantay De Wayracpuncu Group

texts.es:
Gregoria, tiene 53  años, es casada, tiene nueve hijos y vive en la comunidad D. Phiry  a 10 minutos D. Ollantaytambo.

Gregoria nos cuenta. - En mi banco comunal “Ollantay D. Wayracpuncu”  somos 15 integrantes (7 mujeres y 8 varón), la junta directiva está conformada por Juan que es el presidente, Elva que es la Tesorera,  José Darío que  es la secretaria y Augusto que es la fiscal. Las reuniones  son cada treinta días en la oficina central D. la Asociación Arariwa seD. Ollantaytambo y en esta oportunidad  me eligieron a mí como representante del banco comunal para dar mi testimonio D. mi principal actividad económica.  

“Gregoria hace 3 años que participa en el banco comunal Ollantay D. Wayracpuncu la Unidad D. Micro finanzas D. la  Asociación Arariwa”.

Gregoria su principal actividad económica es la venta y compra D. animales menores como por ejemplo cuyes, gallinas, etc.  Sus clientes vienen D. las ciudades Machupicchu y Ollantaytambo a comprar  cuyes. Sus actividades económicas complementarias son cultivar verduras  y crianza D. truchas.  Gregoria requiere el préstamo para comprar cuyes y gallinas.  

La mayoría D. los socios son comerciantes por ejemplo  algunos se dedican a la  venta D. comestibles,  alimentos preparados, artesanía, comida, alimentos, medicamentos, cd’s y otros socios brindan servicios como por ejemplo son obreros, albañiles, transportistas, etc. La mayoría D. los socios son puntuales y responsables con las cuotas.   

La ciudad D. Urubamba se encuentra a una hora y diez minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco.
texts.en:
Gregoria is 53 years old, married, and has nine children. She lives in the community of Phiry, which is ten minutes away from Ollantaytambo.

Gregoria says that her Communal Bank “Ollantay D. Wayracpuncu” consists of 15 members (7 women and 8 men). The board of directors consists of Juan who serves as president, Elva who serves as treasurer, José Darío who serves as secretary, and Augusto who serves as auditor. They meet every thirty days at the central office of Asociación Arariwa in Ollantaytambo. Gregoria says she was selected to represent the Communal Bank by providing testimony about her business activity. She joined the Communal Bank “Ollantay D. Wayracpuncu” three years ago as part of the microfinance unit of Asociación Arariwa. Gregoria buys and sells small animals such as guinea pigs, chickens, etc. Her customers come from the cities of Machupicchu and Ollantaytambo to buy guinea pigs. Her business activities complement her other pursuits, which incluD. farming and raising trout. Gregoria needs a loan to buy guinea pigs and chickens.

Most of the members are merchants who sell products such as groceries, prepared foods, handicrafts, snacks, medicines, and CDs. Others proviD. services such as farm labor, bricklaying, transportation, etc. The majority of the members are punctual and responsible with their loan payments.

The city of Urubamba is located an hour and ten minutes away from the city of Cusco.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase guinea pigs & chickens

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi (1veuve et 3 mariées) vivent dans des  familles monogames, ayant en moyenne 34 ans, 4 enfants et habitant toutes  le quartier Darsalam, Commune Urbaine de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de mariage.
 Les membres du groupe Benkadi commercialisent des draps de lit, des  rideaux, des chaussures et du charbon de bois. 
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur 7ème prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé les six précédents. 
Madame Tenemba Djiré à la différence des autres membres de son groupe porte son activité génératrice de revenus sur le commerce de charbon de bois et  cela depuis cinq ans. 
Elle utilisera son prêt pour acheter : 20  chargements de charrettes en charbon de bois qui lui sont fournies par les exploitants organisés de bois et de charbon de Sakoïba  et par les gros transporteurs venant de Fana et de Zambougou. Elle ravitaille certains fonctionnaires et gargotières de la place et elle vend à domicile en demi gros et au détail,  à crédit et au comptant à une clientèle constituée d’homme et de femmes.  
Madame Tenemba compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 68.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, à compléter son trousseau de mariage et contribuer à la prise en charge de certaines dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group (one widow and three married women) live in monogamous families and are, on average, 34 years old with three children. They all live in the Darsalem district in the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other as neighbors, friends and through marriage ties. The members of the Benkadi group deal in bed sheets, curtains, shoes and charcoal. The women of the Benkadi group are on their seventh loan, after having properly repaid the previous six. Mrs. Tenemba Djiré, unlike the other members in her group, makes her money selling charcoal, and has been doing so for five years. She will use her loan to buy 20 cartloads of charcoal supplied to her by organized distributors of charcoal in Sakoïba and by wholesale transporters coming from Fana and Zambougou. She supplies certain local officials and restaurant owners, selling door to door in bulk and at retail, on credit and in cash, to a clientele of men and women. Madame Tenemba plans to clear a monthly profit of 68,000FCFA which will be used to repay her loan, to complete her marriage trousseau, and to contribute to meeting certain family expenses.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy charcoal

loans.name: Nyetaa Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Nyetaa sont au nombre de quatre, toutes mariées  dans des  familles polygames et ayant en moyenne 38 ans, 7 enfants, elles habitent toutes  le quartier Darsalam, Commune Urbaine de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié, de mariage et  de leurs activités commerciales qui n’est autres que l’achat vente d’articles divers : des habits, des draps de lit, des cosmétiques et des  déodorants. 
C’est le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce qui les motiva à collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et elles sont à leur 7ème  prêt solidaire. 
Madame Salimata G. est un des membres du groupe qui excelle  dans l’achat vente de cosmétiques et d’habits. 
Elle compte utiliser  son prêt pour acheter : deux douzaines de cartons de parfums et déodorants  de variétés et de qualités différentes. 
Elle s’approvisionne généralement à Bamako et quelques fois à Ségou.  Elle revend ses produits à domicile, au grand marché de Ségou  les jours de foire. 
Elle  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, contribuer à l’achat de nourriture et participer aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, funérailles).
texts.en:
The four members of the Nyetaa group are all married and living in polygamous families. On the average, they are 38 years of age and have seven children. All of them live in the Darsalam district, urban community of Ségou (the 4th administrative district of Mali). They know each other as neighbors, friends or family members, and their commercial activity consists in purchasing and reselling miscellaneous articles: clothing, bed linens, cosmetics and deodorants. It is the need to boost their business capital which has motivated them to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso. They are now on their 7th group loan. Mrs. Salimata G. is one of the group members who excel in selling cosmetics and clothing. She plans to use her loan to purchase two dozen boxes with perfumes and deodorants of various types and quality grades. She usually purchases her stock in Bamako and sometimes in Ségou. She sells her wares at the big market of Ségou on market days. She hopes to achieve a monthly income of 65,000 West African Francs which will be used to repay her loan, and allow her to contribute to the cost of food and social events (weddings, baptisms, funerals).

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cosmetics [for resale]

loans.name: Maria Leonarda

texts.es: La señora Leonarda E. tiene 44 años, tiene un negocio de venta de tortillas trabaja todos los dias para poder mantenerse bien economicamente, Tiene tambien una venta de Leña por raja. Ella solicita el credito para poder comprar maiz por quintal y leña para poder concinar con ella. La señora Leonarda sueña con poder poner una tortilleria mas, en un futuro no muy lejano.
texts.en:
Sra. Leonarda E. is 44 years old and has a business selling tortillas. She works every day to support herself financially. Leonarda also has a separate business selling firewood by the piece.

She is requesting a loan to purchase corn by the quintal (1 quintal = 100 kg) and firewood for cooking. Sra. Leonarda dreams of opening another tortilla shop in the not too distant future.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn & firewood

loans.name: Cristian

texts.es: Cristian P. S., tiene la edad de 23 años, está casado, tiene 1 hijo de un años, que es su mayor prioridad. El crédito lo quiere para la siembra y la compra de insumos para el desarrollo del cultivo de tiquisque. La idea es  darle el adecuado mantenimiento al cultivo de tiquisque, para que cuando estén listos para cosechar los puedan vender y obtener mayores ganancias. El desea poder asistir el cultivo para lograr un mejor desarrollo del mismo,  y así lograr una mejor producción.Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Cristian tiene muchos años de experiencia en la agricultura.El está seguro de que le va a ir muy bien en el nuevo  proyecto.El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
Cristian P. S. is 23 years old, married, and a one year old son who is his highest priority. This loan will be used to buy supplies for planting and growing “tiquisque” (a tuber crop similar to taro root). He wants to adequately maintain his crops so that he can generate better revenues when it comes time to harvest and sell his output. Cristian also attends to his crops as a means of self-development so that he can continue to improve production. This is his first loan with FUDECOSUR and he is very happy with the services that have been provided. Don Cristian has many years of experience in agriculture. He is sure that he will do very well in this new project. Cristian hopes in the future to provide his family a better quality of life and greater financial stability. In addition, he wants to continue growing as a person and as producer.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase farming supplies for growing “tiquisque”

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a leather embroidery machine & materials for making sandals

loans.name: Segundo Jose

texts.es:
Segundo N. de 37 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín (barrio muy humilde, con casas de caña y  caminos de tierra y asfalto) de Guayaquil. Su casa es de caña y no cuenta con los servicios básicos. Su esposa le ayuda en la tienda cuando el sale a vender mariscos en una bicicleta. Ellos tienen dos hijos de 9 y 3 años. 

Segundo vendía mariscos en todo fortín repartiéndolos en bicicletas, pero como el era el único ingreso económico en su hogar decidió invertir sus ahorros en arroz, azúcar y construyo con caña la parte delantera de su casa para hacer una tienda. Poco a poco con la ayuda de su esposa pudo tener una pequeña tienda. 

Ahora el trabaja con su esposa en la tienda desde las 06h00 hasta las 22h00 todos los días, también vende mariscos en su tienda pero para tener mejores ingresos en ocasiones  el sale a vender mariscos en su bicicleta mientras que su esposa atiende la tienda. Venden arroz, bebidas, enlatados, mariscos etc. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, bebidas y azúcar para su tienda. En el futuro quiere construir su casa de cemento y que sus hijos puedan estudiar.
texts.en:
Segundo N. is 37 years old and lives in a suburban area of Guayaquil called Fortín (a very humble neighborhood with reed homes and both dirt and asphalt roads). His house is made of cane and does not have have basic services. His wife helps him in the store when he goes out on his bike to sell shell fish. They have two children ages nine and three. Segundo used to sell shell fish all over Fortin on his bicycle, but since this was his only way of earning a living for his home, he decided to invest his savings in rice, sugar, and building a store in the front part of his home with cane. Bit by bit, with the help of his wife, he was able to build a small store. He now now works with his wife in the store from 6 in the morning until 9 every day. He sells shellfish in his store, but to earn more he occasionally goes out on his bike to sell while his wife looks after the store. They sell rice, drinks, canned food, shell fish, etc. He will buy rice, drinks, and sugar for his store with this loan. In the future, he would like to build a cement house and help his children study.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rice, sugar, drinks

loans.name: Manuela De Jesus

texts.es:
Doña Manuela  es madre de cuatro hijos, de edad de 54 años, trabaja como cocinera a la policía nacional, también ayuda a la venta de colchones negocio que administran con su esposo. Que desde hace años lograron formar con ahorros propios y financiamientos que la institución dio.
