loans.name: Christie

texts.en:
Christie L. is a 31-year-old married woman from Lanang, Morong, Rizal. She is blessed with one son, Dave, who is 7-years-old. She is a member of the Lanang Center in Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) Rizal Central Branch. 

With her husband’s support, she is a very strong-minded woman and she notes that she works hard to better her life. Despite hardships brought about by poverty, Christie remains strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. Her aspiration to give her family a brighter future is what motivates her all day. To make a good living, she operates a farming business. She has been engaged in this business for four years. 

She joined ASHI, a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2009. During the course of her membership, she has been a good performer with respect to her credit rating (basis of loans). She is now applying for her third loan; this time in the amount of 15,000 PHP to pay for raw materials including inventories of rice seeds, fertilizers and other supplies. She is positive that, with access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva, her dreams of building a comfortable house and funding her son's education needs will be achieved.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials including inventories of rice seeds, fertilizers and other supplies.

loans.name: Koem

texts.en:
Mrs. Koem U. lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province and she is 39 years old. She owns a general store in the local village and her husband, Mr. Touch Thou, is a farmer who owns seven hectares of land where he cultivates rice to sell to support his family. Through these activities, the couple supports their two children who are attending the local public school. 

They have a problem in that her husband’s field is a long way from an irrigation system. So, to improve the rice production, Mrs. Koem U. is requesting a loan to buy gasoline. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy gasoline

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda is 33 years old, married, and has three children. She lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines. Her husband works as a rice vendor. To provide additional income for her family, Erlinda is starting a business buying and selling rice in the neighborhood. She is ambitious and determined to launch a successful business venture of her own. Erlinda would like to receive a loan to purchase rice inventory. Since the beginning of her membership in Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Erlinda is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams. Her long-term goals are to build a sustainable business, to fund her grandchildren’s college education, and to construct a more durable home that can withstand flooding common in her town. With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her new business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase rice inventory

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny S. lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She was born in 1971. She is a farmer who owns a 2.4-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support the family. Her husband, Mr. Cham Roeun Orem, is a fisherman and is shown in the photo with her. This couple does not have any children.

Her problem is that her field has infertile soil, it is a long way from an irrigation system and it has a lot of insects. So, to improve rice production, Mrs. Vanny S. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and to hire farming laborers to plow the rice field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, and to hire laborers to plow the field

loans.name: Suvineetha

texts.en:
Suvineetha is a 53-year-old woman living in Telijjawila, part of the Matara area of southern Sri Lanka.  She has four children: two sons and two daughters.

Suvineetha and her husband have managed a business selling clothes at a public fair for 25 years. Suvineetha has requested a 45,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help this business. 

Thank you for taking time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

(Suvineetha is pictured above with her husband.)

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Von

texts.en:
Mr. Von D. and his family are living in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. He is 58 years old.  He is a cow middleman who earns some money to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Oran Lay, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to help support the family. He is the father of a child who is a security guard.

His problems are that his field has infertile soil, it is a long way from an irrigation system and it has a lot of insects. Thus, to improve the production of rice, Mr. Von D. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, pesticide, and to hire farming laborers to plow the rice field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, pesticide, and hire laborers to plow the field

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim, 50, lives in Lahore, known as the heart of Pakistan, with her husband and five daughters in a small two-room house. Her husband works in Marriage Hall as a cleaner, but his income is not sufficient to maintain the family. She also worries about her daughters’ marriages. 

Therefore, a few years ago Shamim started her business of cloth selling, an enterprise she has steadily expanded into the cloth market, where she obtains orders and travels to various cities to purchase embroidered dresses such as Multan and Faisalabad.
She purchases clothes from these cities because of their cheap rates and good designs. 

Shamim earns from Pak Rs. 10,000 to 15,000 on a monthly basis but earns more on occasions such as Eid  and marriage functions. She lives with a dream of someday opening her own boutique where she can sell embroidered dresses and get the full profits of selling.  Shamim is now requesting a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva) to purchase more dresses to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase embroidered dresses to sell

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny C. is from the village of Barangay Villa Coloma, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Jenny sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Jenny has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $150 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jenny joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenny has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jenny is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Srey Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey Mom H. and her family live in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She was born in 1980. She is a farmer who owns a 2.9-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her problems are that her rice field has infertile soil, it is a long way from an irrigation system and it has a lot of insects. So, to improve rice production, Mrs. Srey Mom H. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, pesticide, and to hire farming laborers to plow her rice field. 

Her husband, Mr. Sina Dieb, is a construction worker and is also a fisherman. He is shown in the photo with her. The couple supports two children, one of whom is studying in the local public school, while the younger one is only three years old.

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en: Geoffrey K. is a hardworking 48-year-old businessman. He is married and blessed with four children, two of whom are attending a technical institute. He has owned and operated a pub located in Nakaiba A (Banya Nakaiba) for over ten years, and he will use the loan to purchase more crates of beer, sodas, a variety of wines, etc., to sell. Geoffrey dreams of owning a wholesale business, so that he can supply in bulk and enable his children to become well-educated and to secure good jobs.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer, sodas, wines, etc.

loans.name: Carlina's Group

texts.en:
Carlina R. is from the town of Benito Soliven. She is the leader of a 12-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Carlina R..
Carlina is 49 years old and single. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making dimsum and selling it to the local community. Carlina is just starting this business.
In 2009, Carlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Carlina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Teav

texts.en: Mrs. Teav P. is a villager in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She was born in 1982. She is a tailor in the local village and her husband, Mr. Sidat Orem, is a fisherman and a farmer who owns a three-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. Although they try to work hard with their careers, they don't earn enough income because their rice field has infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. So to improve their rice production, Mrs. Teav P. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide, and to hire a machine to plow her field. She is the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and hire a machine to plow her field

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
"H. Nguyễn Thị (20201070009) is a 30 year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. H. is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Trung Bạn 2 - Nhóm 08 (8).

H. is married and has 3 school-aged children. To making a living, H. owns & operates a business butchering & selling pork in the local community.  H. has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,800,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2009, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,256,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is  requesting a new loan of 6,496,000 VND, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the H.'s 2nd loan from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20201070008) is a 33 year-old female who is requesting a 4,256,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Nghiêm Thị H. (20201070044) is a 20 year-old female who is requesting a 4,256,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.


3.  Nguyễn Thị S. (20201070045) is a 58 year-old female who is requesting a 7,392,000 VND loan to support her service-based business.


4.  Nghiêm Thị H. (20201070042) is a 26 year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.


5.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20201070043) is a 27 year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her service-based business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


H. Nguyễn Thị (20201070009) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  H. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Trung Bạn 2 - Nhóm 08 (8).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các pH. thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ giết mổ & bán T.t heo trong cộng đồng địa pH..  H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 3.800.000 VND.  Vào 2009, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  H. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.256.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.496.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20201070008) là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.256.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Nghiêm Thị H. (20201070044) là 20 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.256.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  Nguyễn Thị S. (20201070045) là 58 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


4.  Nghiêm Thị H. (20201070042) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


5.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20201070043) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna B. is from the village of Barangay Villa Coloma, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 48 years old. Lorna is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Lorna owns & operates a general store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lorna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 27000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Lorna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Osaretin

texts.en:
Tailoring is a business that has brought joy to Osaretin. All these are seen in the success the business has brought to his life. People from different parts of his city patronize his business. He also sells tailoring materials and sarongs to boost his profit. He hopes for a loan of NGN100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell.

At 26, Osaretin is married with 2 children. They live in Edo State, Nigeria. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Kusumawathi

texts.en:
Kusumawathi is a 48-year-old married woman living in Telijjawila, part of the Matara area of Sri Lanka.  She has three daughters who are 8, 6, and 4 years old.

Kusumawathi has run a tuition class (private education service) for four years, teaching local children in her area.  She has asked for a 20,000 rupee (LKR) loan from BRAC Sri Lanka, to help purchase desks for her pupils in the classroom.

Thank you for taking time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase desks

loans.name: Mrs. Kimly San Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank is comprised of seventeen people, living in Krang Ta Mung village in Takeo province. Mrs. Kimly S. is a village bank president, selected by all the members. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order improve the living conditions their families. Her problem is that it is time to farm their rice field. So, to improve production rice, Mrs. Kimly S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, to hire farming laborers to plow the rice field, and rest of the loan she wants to start a new business breeding piglets. Her husband, Mr. Kork Horn, is a construction worker. They have three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is helping to do farming, and the other is studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, to hire farming laborers to plow rice field.

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en:
Tereza A. is currently in the business of selling various foodstuffs at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and cassava flour.  Tereza is 41 years old and is married to a husband who is a captain in the police force. She has 6 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a super market.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of rice and cassava flour

loans.name: Brigida's Group

texts.en:
Brigida B. is from the village of Barangay Ibung, VillaverD., Nueva Vizcaya. She is 60 years old. Brigida is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Brigida is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Brigida owns & operates a general store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Brigida has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Brigida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Brigida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Brigida is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the product offering. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Brigida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a carpenter and he has been using this business to care of his family. He lives in Edo state. He is proud of his occupation as he makes chairs, tables and cabinets. He is in need of the loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more furniture materials like foams, nails and woods to boost his business.

He is 56 years old and married with 6 children. His children are doing well at school. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more furniture materials to boost his business

loans.name: Unjima

texts.en:
Unjima I. is currently in the business of selling weaving materials in a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to stock more weaving materials to sell.  Unjima is 34 years old and is married to a husband who is a head teacher. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to employ one lady to work for her the salon.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more weaving materials to sell

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
Taiwo is 42 years old and married with 4 children. His wife is a trader and she also supports their home. With over 7 years in the rearing and sales of poultry birds and with considerable years with LAPO he will want to expand his business. 

Taiwo is requesting for a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more poultry birds to boost his business. He is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry birds

loans.name: Duyen

texts.en: Duyen T. D. was born in 1983. She is married with three children. She lives in luong Quy village with her husband and her children. She has a store where she sells poultry food. Her husband is a taxi driver. They have a monthly income of about 8,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and has repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 8,066,000 VND to expand her store.

loans.use: to expand her store.

loans.name: Furu

texts.en:
Furu M. is currently in the business of selling bread, tomatoes, and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to stock cooking oil to sell.  Furu is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 33 years old and married with 2 children. His children are in primary school. He lives in Benin City. He sells fish to make a living. He has been in this business since 3 years

He needs the loan of NGN100,000 to purchase more of fish to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Srean Minh Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of eleven people who live in Angkanh village, in Takeo province. They will use the loan for different purposes with the goal of improving their businesses in the future. Mrs. Srean M. is a village bank president who has been selected by all the members. She is a farmer who owns a one point twelve-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice. The rice is then sold to support her family's living. Her problem is that their rice field is on time to harvest, but she did not enough money to support it. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Srean M. is seeking a loan to hire farming laborers to harvest her rice field in this current year. Her husband, Mr. Khy Sor, is a construction worker and she has four children, three of whom are enrolled in local public school, while the youngest one is three years old. Mr. Hieng Lach is a group guarantor, so he is presented in the photo.

loans.use: To hire farming laborers to harvest her rice field.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a mother of 2 and she is 35 years of age. She sells groceries and foodstuffs in her shop to make a living in Lagos and she has been in the business for over 10 years. Her husband is doing well in his personal business. They work hard in order to meet up with their family responsibility. 

Juliet wants to rent a big shop so that she can expand the size of her business by buying more groceries and foodstuffs to sell and increase her profit. She hopes for the loan of NGN100, 000 to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell to her costumers. She appreciates all lenders for their good work.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila D. is from the village of Barangay Villaros, Bagabag, Neuva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Mila is widowed and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Mila owns & operates a general store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Mila has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mila is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Mila from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine S. is from the village of Brgy.Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 43 years old. Josephine is married and has 6 children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Josephine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 57 years old. She is married to a retired civil servant and they are blessed with 6 children. She is a native of Bini and most people in her community call her nurse. She has been in business since 1986. 

Elizabeth needs the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden B. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to import more chickens and bags of cassava flour from Uganda.

Kiden is 41 years old and is married to a watchman. She has five children, two of whom go to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, Kiden hopes to be able to extend the floor of her hotel (restaurant).

loans.use: To import more chickens and bags of cassava flour from Uganda

loans.name: James Gichure

texts.en:
James is 39 years old, is married to Virginia, and they have two daughters.

James has been running a transport business for the past three years. He also sells fresh milk as his other source of income. 

James was introduced to KADET through an existing KADET client. He plans to expand his business with the loan he has applied for so that he can supply more milk to hotels and schools near his home town.

James hopes to buy a power saw for timber extraction so as to sell firewood. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman who is honest, optimistic and determined.

loans.use: To supply more milk to hotels and schools

loans.name: Chan's Group

texts.en:
The four people who make up this group loan live in Pump Edth village in Takeo province. They will use the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Chan P. is the group leader who has been selected by all the members. She is a vegetable and fruit seller in her local village and her husband, Mr. Ry Lay, is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land to grow rice and vegetables to sell to support his family. Although they try to work hard, they can not earn enough income. So to improve their family's living conditions, they want to start a new business but they do not have enough money. 

Thus, Mrs. Chan P. is applying for a loan to buy chickens, piglets, and pig and chicken feed for the animals. She supports two children, one of whom is enrolled in local public school, while the younger one is only four years old.

loans.use: To buy chickens, piglets, and pig and chicken feed

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary has a restaurant where she sells cooked foods of various kinds. Due to the ways she prepares her foods, she is able to win the heart of her customers. She is 5 years old in this business. She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to cook and sell. 

Mary is married with 4 children. She is 45 years old. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports their home. She appreciates LAPO and Kiva  lenders for their help.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to coo and sell

loans.name: Joanne

texts.en:
Joanne C. is from the village of Brgy.Villaros, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 30 years old. Joanne is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Joanne owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling mobile phone credit loads in the local community. Joanne has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joanne joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joanne has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional phone credit loads to sell. Joanne is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Joanne from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Suzy

texts.en: Suzy F. is currently in the business of importing rolls of cloth from Khartoum and selling them in Juba and is requesting a loan to stock more rolls of cloth to sell. Suzy is 44 years old and is married to an inspector in the labor office. She has seven children and only four go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. loans.use: To stock more rolls of cloth to sell

loans.name: Moeun's Group

texts.en:
The four people who make up this loan group live in a village in Takeo province. They will each use the loan for different purposes so that it can improve their businesses in the future. 

Mr. Moeun M. is the group leader who has been selected by all the members. He is a construction worker and aside from this, he sells beds in his local village also. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. So to improve his business, Mr. Moeun M. is asking for a loan to buy five beds for resale. His wife, Mrs. Van Oruk, is a recycler and he is the father of five children, four of whom are studying in local public school, while the youngest one is only five years old.

loans.use: To buy five beds for resale

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en:
Lovelyn is married with 7 children and they are in primary and secondary school respectively. She is 38 years of age and she lives with her family in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells groceries, foodstuffs and drinks to sustain her and support her husband in keeping their home.  
Lovelyn started the business 15 years ago. She said she needs extra capital in the business that will enable her increase her stock and profitability. In future she hope to have a deep freezer in her shop. She is requesting for the loan amount of NGN50, 000 to purchase more groceries, foodstuffs, and drinks to sell. She thanks lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, foodstuffs, and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Silas

texts.en:
Silas K. is 61 years old and married to Kimoi Kipsang. They have four children: Jepkemoi (29 years old, female, a primary school leaver); Albert (25 years old, male, a primary school leaver); Kibet (22 years old, a primary school leaver); and Miriam (14 years old, in high school).

Silas runs a kiosk which he started seven years ago. From this he gets a monthly profit of Ksh 1,000. He earns additional income from farming.

Silas has borrowed a loan of Ksh 10,000. He plans to use Ksh 5,000 to buy two sacks of maize, Ksh 3,000 to buy two sacks of rice, Ksh 1,100 to buy a bale of wheat flour and Ksh 900 to buy 50gm packets of Omo (a brand name detergent). All the above items will be for sale in his shop.

Silas was introduced to KADET by a credit officer. He does his business at Ngolong in Kabernet, Kenya which is a cold place. His customers are faithful. If this loan boosts his business, he will use the extra profit to expand his business and educate his children.

Silas dreams and hopes of buying a plot of land and owning a car. He describes himself as hardworking and God-fearing.

loans.use: To purchase stock for his store

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary lives in Edo state with her family and she sells groceries and drinks. She has been in this business for long. Mary is happy in her business because it has given her more focus. She is married to a sanitary inspector and they are blessed with 4 children who are in school. With the proceeds of the business she has been able to support her family meaningfully.

She needs the loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Salinah

texts.en:
Salina C. was born in 1974. She is married to Joseph Tarus who is a 45-year-old soldier. They have two children: Sharon (10 years old, in primary school) and Mary (10 years old, in primary school).

Salina sells fruits and vegetables and started this business one year ago. The business gives her a monthly profit of Ksh 6,000 and her husband’s salary brings in additional income. 

Salina did not borrow from another source before KADET. She was introduced to KADET by its staff and clients. She has borrowed a loan of Ksh 10,000 from KADET and, from this loan, Ksh 8,000 will be used to purchase five iron sheets and timber for constructing a premises for her business. The remaining balance will be used to purchase livestock.

Salina's business is in Kabarnet Town, opposite the municipal council building. Her clients pay in cash. If this loan boosts her business, she will use the extra profit to buy goats for her family and educate her children.

Salina dreams of and hopes to buy a plot of land and use it to construct a house for her family. She also dreams of becoming a wholesale vegetable vendor.

Salina describes herself as an honest and God-fearing lady.

loans.use: To construct premises for her business and buy livestock

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is from the village of Brgy.Villaros, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 47 years old. Elizabeth is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. loans.name: Esiya

texts.en: Esiya S. is currently in the business of baking and selling bread and cakes and selling ice cream at the market and is requesting a loan to bake more cakes to sell. Esiya is 25 years old and is married to a builder. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. loans.name: Mrs. San Heng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The nine people who make up this village bank loan live I. Pring village I. the Takeo province. They will all use their loan for different purposes to improve their businesses I. the future. 

Mrs. San H. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. She is widow with a child who is a farmer like she is. Now her problem is that it is time to harvest her rice field, but she does not have enough money to support it. So, to improve her rice production, Mrs. San H. is applying for a loan to hire farming laborers to harvest her rice field I. this current year.

loans.use: To hire farming laborers to harvest her rice field

loans.name: Victoira

texts.en:
Victoria sells foodstuffs like rice, palm oil. She has been in this business since 3 years. She has also been able to support her family with the needed financial support. She needs the loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

Victoria is 35 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She lives in Benin City, Edo State Nigeria. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan K. is a single, 33-year-old lady who has two children: Rebbecca (10 years old, in primary school) and Justus (7 years old, in primary school).

Joan runs a secondhand-clothes business which she started three years ago. From this business she earns a profit of Ksh 10,000 every month. She earns additional income from farming.

Joan has borrowed a loan of Ksh 20,000 from KADET. Half of the loan will be used to buy more blouses, Ksh 5,000  will be used to buy jumpers and Ksh 5,000 to buy hairnets.

Existing clients of KADET introduced Joan to the micro-finance organization and this is the first financial institution from which she has borrowed. Joan’s business is in Kabarnet Town. Her clients are honest.

If this loan boosts her business, Joan will use the extra profit to expand the business. She dreams of opening a boutique and transforming her business from the sale of secondhand clothes to the sale of new clothes.

Joan describes herself as an honest, God-fearing and hardworking woman.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her used-clothing retail business

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en: Gemma J. is from the village of Brgy. Villaros, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 34 years old. Gemma is married and has three infant children. To make a living, Gemma runs a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of fruits in the local community. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Gemma joined ASKI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Gemma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: John

texts.en:
John L. is a hardworking businessman, twenty-nine years old. He is legally married and blessed with two children, both in school.

John operates a clothing business and he has run his business since 2004. He is using the loan to purchase clothes from Kampala to sell in Masaka along Engine Street. He will purchase kid’s clothes: that is to say dresses, skirts, tops, and so forth.

loans.use: To purchase more children's clothes to sell

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline A. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and groundnut phase (peanut butter) and is requesting a loan to stock bread and onions to sell. Jackline is 17 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot and build a rental property. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bread and onions to sell

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en: Rosalinda M. is from the village of Brgy. Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 51 years old. Rosalinda is married. To make a living, Rosalinda runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Rosalinda joined ASKI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Rosalinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Margaret Wambui

texts.en:
Margaret Wambui K. is 38 years old. She is married to Ben and she is the mother of two young children. 

Margaret has a vegetables business that she has been running for the last three years on a busy street in Narok Town.

Margaret learned about KADET from other women who are already registered as clients. This will be her fourth loan. She is planning to increase her supplies with the loan. With the profits that she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to open another shop and create employment for other people.

Margaret’s future dream is that she will be able to build her store and her own house. She believes she is hardworking and that she can attain her goal by having access to credit.

loans.use: To buy more cabbages and onions

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria run her personal business in Lagos, she is into buying and selling of groceries and drugs to costumers at retail prices. She has been managing the business for the past 10 years now. With the proceeds from the business she could take care of her family financial needs. 

32 years old Victoria is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a civil servant and they live together in Lagos. She is happy about her business and she wish to expand it in future. She hopes for the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more groceries and drugs to sell as this will attracts discount, improve sales and increase her profit. This she said will be reinvest into the business and sponsor her children education. She expresses her thanks to all.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drugs to sell

loans.name: Zenaida's Group

texts.en:
Zenaida N. is from the village of Brgy.Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 59 years old. Zenaida is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Zenaida is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Kingsley

texts.en:
Kingsley is a retired soldier and also a community leader. He took into cocoa farming to be able to support his home. This also keeps him busy and energetic. His wife sells drinks. He has been in this business for long. He needs the loan of NGN100,000 to purchase more chemicals for weed control on his cocoa farm and also to clear his farm land for better yield.

He is blessed with 10 children. He thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more chemicals for weed control on his cocoa farm and also to clear his farm

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan R. is currently in the business of selling dried fish and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell. Juan is 40 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 5 children, and 3 of them go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs, as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian sells foodstuffs like garri (cassava flakes), rice, stock fish and more at retail price to costumers and she has been in the business for the past 8 years. She is 40 years old, married with 3 children and they live in Lagos. She sees her business as her means of livelihood. She needs the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob is into two businesses and his business has really been flourishing. He is into the sales of building materials and farming. His primary trade is farming. He has a cocoa farm and he has been in this business for a long time. He needs the loan of NGN 100,000 to clear his farm and purchase more building materials to sell. 

 He is 48 years old and married to a trader. They are blessed with 7 children. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To clear his farm and purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị (20213030040) is a 51-year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  L. is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Cầu Gạo nhóm 09 (9).

L. is married and has 2 adult-aged children.  To making a living, L. manufactures and sells bamboo products to local businesses and community members.  L. has been engaged in this business for more than 5 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month.

In 2008, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  L. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,360,000 VND from SEDA, which she used to purchase raw materials.  She is now requesting a new loan of 4,256,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings.  The loan will be the 3rd loan she has taken out from SEDA.  L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Đào Thị D. (20213030041) is a 28-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,392,000 VND loan to support her business of making and selling food.


2.  Trần Thị T. (20213030042) is a 25-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,496,000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business.


3.  Trần Thị H. (20213030043) is a 34-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,496,000 VND loan to support her general store.


4.  Đỗ Thị L. (20213030044) is a 32 year-old woman who is requesting a 7,392,000 VND loan to support her business of making and selling food.


5.  Nghiêm Thị T. (20213030045) is a 27-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,496,000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.


6.  Nghiêm Thị T. (20213030046) is a 42-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,496,000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

Stella Q. sells bread and groundnut products at market.  She is requesting a loan to stock cooking oil to sell.  Stella is 19 years old and is single.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

texts.en:
Marissa Marivic O. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal West, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 41 years old. Marissa Marivic is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marissa Marivic is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marissa Marivic owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing & shoes in the local community. Marissa Marivic has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marissa Marivic joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marissa Marivic is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the first loan taken out by Marissa Marivic from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
