loans.name: Toyi

texts.en:
Cellophane bags are a business that gives money to Toyi. She sees this business as a major source of her income. Toyi has been in this business for long. She is a LAPO client. She needs the loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cellophane bags to sell.

Toyi is 32 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are in secondary and primary school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase cellophane bags to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence has operated an agriculture supply shop in Naivasha town for the last 7 years, supplying farm supplies to the area's residents.  This has proved to be a successful venture as most of the people in her area practice farming.  She is 46 years old, married to Charles Wainaina, and they have 4 children.

She was introduced to KADET by a friend.  This will be her third loan after successfully repaying two previous two loans on time.  She plans to add fertilizer stock in her shop, which is in demand during the planting season.

Florence hopes to open another shop outside town, closer to farmers who currently must travel to town to shop for farm supplies.

loans.use: To add fertilizer to sell

loans.name: Magi

texts.en:
Magi F. sells bread and tea on the street in the evenings.  She is requesting a loan to buy stock of tins of milk and bags of sugar for her tea.  Magi is 30 years old and is married; her husband is an engineer. She has 3 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy stock of milk and sugar to make tea to sell

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph has seen tremendous growth in his retail shop since opening it four years ago. He now wants to diversify and start selling bicycle spare parts.  He operates in the busy Naivasha town.  He is 53 years old, married to Ann Njeri and they have 4 children.  

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy bicycle parts to sell to diversify his product range.  Bicycles are popular in this part of the country and bicycle owners have to travel far to get spare parts, so Joseph has decided to bring the parts closer to the people.

He hopes to capitalize on the opportunity to be the first seller of bicycle spare parts in his area, and make a profit from the business.

loans.use: To buy bicycle spare parts to sell

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson runs a food stall and retail shop in Naivasha, Kenya. He is 39 years old, married to Ann Njeri, and they have three children who go to school.  

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 2nd loan. He paid off the first loan of KES 15,000 successfully and on time. He plans to buy sugar, flour and rice, in bulk, to sell in his retail shop. He hopes his retail shop will grow into a wholesale store in the future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, flour and rice in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy has run his barber shop in Naivasha town for 9 years now. He is 31 years old, married to Lewinda Adhiambo and they have 2 children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 2nd loan. He paid his first loan of KES 35,000 well and in good time. He plans to use the loan amount to put a music system in his shop; this will attract more clients as they will be entertained as they are receiving haircuts and shaves. The business is so competitive and this is one of the creative ways barber shops can lure in clients.

He hopes his business will grow and even be able to employ other people to help him.

loans.use: To put a music system in his barber shop to attract more clients.

loans.name: Funmiayo

texts.en:
Funmiayo sells drinks and groceries at retail prices to her customers. She is requesting for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more drinks and a fridge.  She hopes this will help cool her drinks which will also attract more customers. 

Funmiayo is 30 years old and she is happily married with 2 children. Her husband is a farmer and he also supports their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and a fridge

loans.name: Jova

texts.en:
Jova M. is currently in the business of selling prepared food at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish and chickens. Jova is 48 years old and is widowed. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more dried fish and chickens.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David has been in the bicycle transportation business in Naivasha town where he ferries people and goods from one place to another, for a fee. He is 39 years old, married to Jacinta Wairimu, and they have 3 children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid off his first loan of KES 15,000 well and in good time. He plans to buy another bicycle with the money from this loan and to set up a shop to sell fruits with the remaining loan funds.

He is saving and wants to upgrade to buy a motorbike, which is faster and more profitable.

loans.use: To buy another bicycle.

loans.name: Chu

texts.en:
T. Chu Thị (20213030009) is a 33-year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong in Bắc Ninh Province. She is married and has three school-age children. To making a living, T. owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling dried goods in the local community. T. has been engaged in this business for over 5 years, and she earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. T. is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by T. from SEDA. T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

T. Chu Thị (20213030009) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 3 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học. Để kiếm sống, T. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh. Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm sấy khô trong cộng đồng địa phương. T. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, T. kiếm được khoảng 5.000.000 VND một tháng.

Vào 2008, T. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. T. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND. Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. T. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.

Về SEDA:
Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy has practiced farming in Naivasha town for the last 20 years. She sells all of her farm output to middlemen who later sell it to the National Cereals Board. She is 46 years old and married to Tonkoi Pareiyo. They have five children.

Lucy was introduced to KADET by her friend, and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the money to harvest her maize and to plant potatoes and cabbage on her land.

Lucy plans to start selling her maize to the National Cereals Board directly, as it is more profitable.

loans.use: To harvest maize on her farm and to plant potatoes and cabbage

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: S. Hussein is a hardworking, thirty-three year old businessman. He resides in Kivumba and he has been running his business for over three years now. He is using the loan to purchase basic items for his boutique; items such as shirts, trousers, baby shawls, towels, dresses, and so forth for sale. He wishes to expand his business from retail sale to a wholesale business.

loans.use: To purchase basic clothing items for his boutique.

loans.name: Alia

texts.en:
Alia A. is currently in the business of selling fish and charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to stock fish to sell. Alia is 25 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 2 children and her children do not go to school yet.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock fish to sell.

loans.name: Friday

texts.en:
Friday 49 years old, happily married with 6 children. His wife is a petty trader and she also supports their home. He sells planks and he is also into farming. With these combined businesses, he hopes to meet the basic needs of his family. He needs the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase planks to sell to his customers.

He thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James has been planting wheat for commercial purposes in Naivasha town for the past 10 years. Wheat is profitable as there is a ready market. The government buys directly from farmers. He is 27 years old, married to Susan L., and they have 2 children.

James was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to buy pesticide for his current crop in the field and also to plant more wheat.  

He plans to buy a tractor in the future, which he will not only use in his farm but he will also hire it out to receive additional income.

loans.use: To buy pesticides and to plant more wheat.

loans.name: Lani's Group

texts.en:
Lani C. is from the village of Simmimbaan. She is 33 years old. Lani is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Lani C.'s Group'.

Lani is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lani owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Lani has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lani joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lani is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Lani from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz is a wife of T. H. and she lives in a mid-size city named Riwind, in Pakistan. Riwind city is famous for its dairy business.
She is 44-year old woman and owns a two room house, in which she has been living with her family for over 10 years. She is an uneducated lady because she lives in a community where people don’t like to send the girls to school for an education. They raise girls with the guidance of managing domestic chores. This same upbringing happened to Shahnaz and she learned the skills of managing domestic chores and cooking. Shahnaz has given birth to four boys. Her eldest son is a painter and paints doors and windows on call. The next to him works in a local factory on a monthly wage. The youngest sons are enrolled in school and are getting an education. Shahnaz's husband is a mason by profession. He has been in this profession for the last 20 years. Shahnaz is a very caring lady. She takes care of their health by cooking good food and presents it to her family on time, which makes them happy when they reach home. 

Shahnaz is a regular client of Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva). She has successfully repaid her three loans to Asasah and now she is applying for a loan for the fourth time. She will use the loan funds to purchase masonery tools so that her husband may earn a good profit from his profession and improve the standard of living for their family.

loans.use: To purchase masonery tools.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina V. is requesting for a larger amount of loan through ASHI. This will finance the growth of her hog fattening business. By fattening a larger volume of hogs, and selling them all together after four months, his proceeds will be much larger. With this plan, she will augment the small income of her husband, who is a hired laborer. This will enable her to support the needs of her eight children, whose ages range from three to 25 years old. Although two of the children work as hired laborers, their income is just small and they still depend on their mother for some of their basic needs. 

Despite being poor and having many children to support, Josefina is still optimistic about achieving her goal of graduating at least one of her children from college. For her business, she hopes to make it more stable and profitable for her children to inherit and manage in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets for fattening.

loans.name: Harun

texts.en:
Harun has been hawking plastic bags in Naivasha town for the last 5 years.  He is 53 years old, married to Mary Njeri, and they have 2 children.  He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan.  The first time, he applied for a loan of Kshs 15,000 which he paid well and on time.  He applied for this loan because he wants to build a kiosk where he can sell the plastic bags from.  He will also be able to buy plastic bags in bulk once he has a place to store them.

In the future he hopes to be a major player in the supply of plastic bags, supplying wholesale to retail sellers.

loans.use: To build a kiosk to sell his plastic bags out of

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a mother of 4 and she is 35 years of age. She is a widow and she takes care of her children all alone in terms of feeding, clothing and sponsoring their education. She sells drinks to earn a living in Lagos and she has been in the business for more than 7 years. 

She hopes for growth in her business and that of her family. She asking for the loan of NGN50, 000 to purchase more drink in crates to sell that will boost her profit margin. 
Ruth is member in LAPO micro finance with good repayment record and she promise to repay her loan as at when due. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drink to sell to sell.

loans.name: Thanh

texts.en: Thanh T. N. was born in 1976. She lives in Luong Quy village. She is married with a son. She is a tailor. Besides that, she breeds pigs and poultry. She has a monthly income of about 2.000.000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and has repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 8.066.000 VND to buy feed for her pigs and poultry.

loans.use: to buy feed for pigs and poultry

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth started farming in 2004 and she has seen her life change as she made profits from her farm.  She has been able to grow her farm business and recently bought another piece of land out of her savings.  She is 30 years old, married to Katangie Allison, and they have 4 children.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the money to cultivate the plot of land she bought and plant snow peas which are in high demand.

After seeing the benefits of farming, she now wants to continue in it and also offer her farm as a research and training center.

loans.use: To cultivate snow peas on her new plot of land

loans.name: Apai

texts.en:
Apai Frabchiska is currently in the business of selling cooking oil, sugar, and charcoal,  and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Apai is 46 years old and is widowed.   She has seven children, and three of  her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family and pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Masio Ene

texts.en:
Masio has been a farmer for the last 9 years, specializing in wheat farming.  She is a 61-year-old widow with 6 children.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan with the organization.  She plans to use the money to buy pesticides for her maturing wheat crop in the farm.

She hopes to buy a tractor in the near future.

loans.use: To buy pesticides for her crop

loans.name: Bose

texts.en:
50 years old Bose  lives in Lagos, she sells foodstuffs and drinks to make her living. She manages the business with the help of her children who sometimes assist her at the shop. She has been in the business for the past 20 years. 

Bose is married with 3 children and her husband is civil servant. She believe in women been a help mate to the men and she do all she could to support and assist her husband in taking care of the home. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN50, 000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
As a loyal member of a Kiva field partner in the Philippines (ASHI), Narcisa S. has been receiving loans since 1998. Loans she received then have enabled her to start up several businesses managed by her. First, she started selling vegetables & fruits and with her next loans, she started a slaughtering business and a “sari-sari” (variety) store. She sells her products directly to people in her village and in a public market. 

Now, Narcisa is requesting another loan from ASHI to support her businesses and to grow them further until such time as they become profitable and stable. She wants to increase the inventory of her store for the convenience of her customers who live around the village. 

Narcisa happily handles her career being a wife, mother, and businesswoman. Her desire to give her children a better life in the future inspired her to have her own businesses and augment her husband’s sporadic income as a government employee. 

Narcisa is a very good member of ASHI who is requesting a new loan of 45,000 Php to realize her dream of buying more vegetables & fruits, pigs to be slaughtered, and to purchase inventory for her store. The pigs that Narcisa slaughters are sold directly to people in different municipalities during market day. Profit from this kind of businesses is quite good compared to other businesses that Narcisa has tried. Furthermore, she wishes to support the education of all her children until they graduate from college and have a better career in the future. With her passion for giving her children a better future, she will be willing to work hard and help her husband earn money through her businesses. 

Narcisa is motivated by her desire for personal development so that one day she can be self-reliant in her businesses. Narcisa enjoys the system of work groups that is implemented by ASHI. She has benefited from hearing the experiences of her fellow group members and also appreciates that the process for securing a loan is convenient for her.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables & fruits, pigs to be slaughtered, and buy inventory for her store

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Huong T. N. was born in 1979. She is married with two children who are going to school. She is a farmer. She is raising ten pigs and poultry. Her family has a monthly income of about 3,500,000 Vietnamdong (VND).  She has participated in SEDA since 2007 and has repaid punctually. She can save money daily, weekly. So she feels happy. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 8,066,000 VND to buy five pigs and feed for them.

loans.use: to buy five pigs and feed for them

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 54 years old and he is married with 6 children. He sells gas and lubricants at retail prices to his customers in Edo state. He has been in this business since 4 years. He needs the loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more lubricants to sell.

Samuel is hard working and he appreciates Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more lubricants to sell

loans.name: Elvis

texts.en:
Elvis, 22 years old, has been doing cross farming on his two plots of land where he has alternated between planting wheat, potatoes and cabbages since 2004.  

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the money to cultivate his land and plant potatoes and cabbages.

In the future he wants to diversify his sources of income and buy a tractor which he will hire out to other farmers.

loans.use: To cultivate his land and plant potatoes and cabbages

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice P. is currently in the business of selling local brew and charcoal out of her home  and is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials.  Joice is 40 years old and is widowed.   She has 5 children, and 3 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more brewing materials

loans.name: Emilie

texts.fr:
Madame Emilie S., âgée de 31 ans, est une infirmière de métier depuis presque 10 ans. Marièe et mère d'un enfant de 6 mois, Madame Emilie sollicite un prêt au niveau de sa caisse U-IMCEC Thiès pour se conformer aux coutumes. En fait son jeune frère doit entrer à la case des hommes et que les coutumes veulent que son frère ou soeur ainé(e) se charge de la cotisation financière. Cette cérémonie est appelée leul ou circoncision communautaire qui a pour objectif de ressusciter un pan important des cultures.
Le leul est considéré pour certains  comme une école de la vie. Il initie les candidats aux rites de la vie. Ainsi, ces candidats participent au leul pour être forgés et non pour se faire plaisir ou faire état de leurs différences sociales. 
Selon les organisateurs, les premiers jours, la plupart des enfants ont du mal à se départir de leurs habitudes, mais à force de recevoir les enseignements de l'encadrement, ils finissent par se ranger.

La plus populaire de ces cérémonies est organisée par intervalle d'années précise au sud du Sénégal en Casamance par les diolas. Cette année, elle va se féter au mois de Juillet prochain. 
Avec ce prêt Madame Emilie S., une diola originaire de Casamance,  compte cotiser pour son jeune frère et respecter une tradition.
texts.en:
Ms. Emilie S., aged 31, has been a nurse by profession for almost ten years.  Married and the mother of a 6-month-old child, she is requesting a loan at the U-IMCEC Thiès branch office to conform to a custom.  That is, her younger brother must enter la case des hommes (the men's hut).  Customs dictate that a boy's older brother or sister is responsible for paying the costs.  This ceremony is called leul, or communal circumcision, and has the purpose of reviving an important aspect of culture.  For some people, leul is considered to be schooling in life.  It initiates the candidates in the rites of life.  Thus, the candidates participate in leul to be recast and molded, not to have fun or to justify their societal differences.   According to the organizers, in the first few days, most of the children have trouble divesting themselves of their ways.  But by dint of the supervised learning, they end up falling in line. In southern Senegal, in Casamance, the most widespread of these ceremonies is organized by the Diola ethnic group for a precise time in the year.  This year, the ceremony is going to be celebrated this July.  With this loan, Ms. Emilie S., a Diola with roots in Casamance, plans on making the payments for her younger brother and respecting a tradition.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Traditional need

loans.name: Ne's Group

texts.en:
The five people who make up this group loan live in Ampil Lech village in Takeo province. They will use the loan for different purposes so that it can improve conditions in their businesses in future. 

Mrs. Ne L. is the group leader who has been selected by all the members. She is a weaver and works at her home. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. Thus, Mrs. Ne L. is applying for a loan to buy more silk. Her husband, Mr. Or Sum, is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land to cultivate rice on to support his family. She is the mother of five children, two of whom help her to do weaving, while another one is enrolled in local public school, and the others are too small to work or study. 

Mrs. Sok Ley Sum and Mr. Kim Houn Chhun are group guarantors so they are present in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Gabrail

texts.en:
Gabrail is a farmer. His farming operation covers different crops like cassava, plantains and okra. When his crops are harvested, he sells some of the farm produce to sellers. He is requesting for a loan of NGN 60,000 to hire laborers to clear his farm   .

Gabrail is 48 years old and married with 4 children. He is very thankful to all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To hire laborers to clear his farm

loans.name: Fatimon

texts.en:
Fatimon sells ice fish buy supplying her customers from one shop to another. She started the business 30 years ago. She likes the nature of her business and she wants more growth in her business and her profit. She is asking for the loan amount of NGN50, 000 to purchase more ice fish to sell to her numerous costumers.

Fatimon is 50 years old, married with 3 children and they are age 20, 14 and 10 years old. Her husband sells building materials and both lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their huge support.

loans.use: To purchase more ice fish to sell.

loans.name: Loku

texts.en:
Loku S. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and fruits such as: passion fruit, paw paws, mangoes, and tomatoes and is requesting a loan to stock more passion fruit to sell.  Loku is 18 years old and is single.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a fridge to keep these fruits fresh and make juice to sell.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more passion fruit to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is proud of her groceries business. With this business she has been able to support her family. She is married to a carpenter and they are blessed with 6 children. Her children are in secondary and primary school. She lives in Benin city , Edo State, 

Recently, Esther has been experiencing increase in the number of customers that patronize her stall especially those purchasing drinks; she needs a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase a deep freezer for cooling her drinks and groceries. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and a deep freezer

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan B. sells soft drinks like water, soda, and juice and is requesting a loan to stock a create of beer to sell. Juan is 23 years old and single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land and build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock a create of beer to sell

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is indeed happy that she took to tailoring. She acquired this skill 3 years ago and it has immensely helped to improve her living standard. She also sells sarongs to boost her business. Faith is 36 years old and married to a soldier. 

Faith is hoping for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Kakenzi Women's Group, Mubende

texts.en:
Hardworking S. Francis, aged 49, is the married father of five children. He went into a business venture of trading in motor spare parts close to seven years ago. His business being strategically located in Ngabano, Mubende town, in western Uganda, Francis gets many customers, earning him 500,000 Ugandan shillings monthly.

With this loan, Francis is looking forward to restocking his business and also doing more advertising to increase the number of his customers. This will help him improve his sales and also be able to take good care of his family requirements.

loans.use: To restock his business and do more advertising

loans.name: Tipatet Ole

texts.en: Tipatet has grown up as a farmer with 30 years experience in farming. He is 48 years old, married to Agnes Nipukue, and they have two children. Farming took him to school and now it is educating his children. He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He wants to use the cash to cultivate his farm and plant wheat. He is planning to employ other people to help him as he ventures into livestock farming in future.

loans.use: To cultivate his farm and plant wheat

loans.name: Saponyo Ole

texts.en: Saponyo started planting wheat in 2004 and the venture so far has been profitable. He is 60 years old and he and his wife, Margaret, have three children. He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash from the loan to buy fertiliser and hire a tractor to prepare his farm for wheat planting. Saponyo plans to start training area residents about farming and its benefits based on his own personal experience.

loans.use: To buy fertiliser and hire a tractor to prepare his farm for wheat planting.

loans.name: Purevchuluun

texts.en:
Purevchuluun S., 33, is married and is the mother of three daughters. She and her family live together in an apartment in Arhangai province, Mongolia and have been living together in their current home for eight years. Her oldest two daughters, aged 9 and 7, attend a local primary school.

Purevchuluun operates a beauty products trading business in her town. She started her business in 2001 with a working capital of 150,000 MNT. With a lot of hard work and determination, today her working capital is 800,000 MNT. She has gained valuable experience and has built a loyal customer base over the past nine years. The whole family supports her business.

Since Purevchuluun started her business, her family's living conditions have improved. With her earnings, she has been providing money for family expenses and paying her children's education fees. She is an open and very hardworking person.

Purevchuluun would like to expand her business and create her own convenient workplace in the future. She has requested an 800,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory for her beauty products trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her shop

loans.name: Osato

texts.en:
Osato is happily married with 3 children. Her husband is an Engineer and he also supports their home. She sells groceries like biscuit, candies, milk, wine, juice and drinks. She has been in this business since 4 years. 

Osato is requesting for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries and a fridge. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and a fridge

loans.name: Myangantsetseg

texts.en:
Myangantsetseg B., 26, lives with her mother and sibling in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian traditional nomadic tent.

Myangantsetseg operates a business selling jeans in her town. Initially, between 2006 and 2008, she started selling a variety of clothing that she purchased from Ereen, a Chinese border town. Since 2008, after those first two years, she has been selling only jeans. She operates her business at a rented counter at a shop called Tansag (Luxurious).

Myangantsetseg is a very hardworking person who has been working hard to provide a better life for her sibling and mother. She has used the profits from her business to pay her sibling's tuition fees as well as the tuition for her own Master's degree program. Her mother is a hairdresser and earns between 50,000 and 60,000 MNT per month.

Myangantsetseg is focused on the future and says, “Now, the most important thing to me is to graduate from the Master’s program in which I am studying. In addition, I would like to enlarge my current house for me and my family.”

Myangantsetseg requested a 1,600,000 MNT loan to purchase a variety of jeans from Ereen, China.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of jeans from Ereen, China

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Madame Coumba S. est mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Agée de 55 ans, Madame Coumba S. est une commerçante et gère une table de légumes depuis 3 ans et depuis un an elle s'est lancée dans la production et la vente de couscous à base de mil. Combattre l'oisiveté et chercher des revenus sont les points intéressants qui ont poussés Madame Coumba S. à s'activer dans le commerce. Elle sollicite cependant un prêt de 50 000 FCFA pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Coumba S. is married and the mother of six children. She is 55 years old and a merchant who has been managing a vegetables table for three years. A year ago, Coumba got started producing and selling millet couscous. Struggling against idleness and seeking revenues are aspects of interest which have pushed her to be active in commerce. Coumba is however requesting a loan of 50,000 francs CFA in order to bolster her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her business

loans.name: Sok Nea's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok Nea H. is the group leader of a group loan which consists of six people. They will use the loan for different purposes so that it can improve their businesses in the future. 

All the members are villagers in Ampil Lech village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sok Nea H. is a weaver at her home. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Sok Nea H. is requesting a loan to bU. silk. Her husband, Mr. Pou Song, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice on to support his family. Through these activities, they support five children, two of whom are helping their mother to weave, while the others are enrolled in local public school.

loans.use: To buy silk

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Javhlantugs

texts.en:
Javhlantugs J., 53, is married and is the father of three children. He and his family live together in a ger (the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent) in Arhangai province, Mongolia. They have been living together in their current home for twenty years. His two daughters, aged 21 and 22, attend university. 

Javhlantugs operates home products trade with his wife at a local market. He has been in this business for many years and the whole family supports his business. He started his business in 1998 with working capital of 80,000 MNT but, with many years of successful operation, today his working capital exceeds 600,000 MNT. He is a very hardworking and open person.

Javhlantugs has been planning to expand his business and create his own convenient workplace. He is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for his business

loans.name: Kolawole

texts.en:
Kolawole is happy that he is into soap making. His greatest challenge is funds and he hopes to overcome the challenge so that he will be able to reach more customers. He hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger in the future. He needs the loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more materials to make more soap to sell.

Kolawole is 60 years and he is married with 4 children. He is living happily in Benin City with his family. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to make more soap to sell

loans.name: Esohe

texts.en:
Esohe is happy with her trade and she has been in this business for long. She sells drinks and sachet water at retail prices to her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase drinks and sachet water to sell.

Esohe is 42 years old and she is married with 5 children.  She lives in Edo State, Nigeria. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and sachet water to sell

loans.name: Ismael

texts.fr: Monsieur Ismael T. est un jeune célibataire né en 1985.  Il s'est investi depuis 3 ans dans le commerce. Actuellement, il est propriètaire de deux cantines d'alimentation générale dont l'une se trouve au marché et l'autre dans son quartier. Monsieur T. gère gère une des cantines tandis que l'autre est gérée par son jeune frère qui l'aidait très souvent dans ce business. Il vend divers produits alimentaires et condiments. Il sollicite cependant un prêt pour s'approvisionner en oignons, tomates et piments.
texts.en:
Mr. Ismael T. is an unmarried young man born in 1985. He has been investing himself in commerce for three years. Currently, he is the owner of two grocery stalls, including one located at the market and another in his district. He manages one of these stalls, while the other is managed by his younger brother, who has helped him quite often in this business. Ismael sells a variety of foods and condiments. He is however requesting a loan for supplies of onions, tomatoes, and chili peppers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies of goods

loans.name: Khoja Panjpiran Group

texts.en:
Kohja M. is the group leader of Khoja Panjpiran Group. He is 45 years old and lives in 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has four children.

Kohja M. has a car parts shop for which he still needs some tools and would like to make his business much larger. He will use his loan to purchase car parts which are not currently available in his shop. He is confident that, after the loan, he can increase his business.

Finally, Kohja M. thanks Kiva for its loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To purchase car parts which are not currently available in his shop
